original: ambhodhi sthalayan dhara tvadharayan garta samakṣetrayan kṣudra kaṇṭakita sthala kusumayan vega śarakṣepayan /🔽voḍha ścāpi vivasvadaśvayadasau śrībhīmasenastvarā ṣaḍ ghastrairvasumuṅa nināya lumaḍīdevīmupa svāminam // //
analyzed: ambhodhi sthalayan dhara tvadharayan garta samakṣetrayan kṣudra kaṇṭakita sthala kusumayan vega śara kṣepayan  voḍhaḥ ca api vivasvat aśvayat asau śrī bhīmasenaḥ tvarā ṣaṣ nināya lumaḍīdevīm upa svāminam  /
translated: Making the ocean a plain, the earth a lower place, the pit a field in front, the small prickly land a flower, the speed a shot of an arrow,🔽and the bow a horse of the sun, that glorious Bhimasena, taking the goddess Lumbaḍeī, brought her to the lord in six ghaṭikās.

original: śrīsvāmī candraṣaṣṭhāṣṭaśaśini niragātkāśikāyāḥ purī svā hṛṣṭo viśveśatuṣṭyā prakṛtibhayavapuḥ kāśijān vādirājān /
analyzed: śrī svāmī candra ṣaṣṭha aṣṭa śaśini niragāt kāśikāyāḥ purī svā hṛṣṭaḥ viśveśa tuṣṭyā prakṛti bhaya vapuḥ kāśi jān vādi rājān
translated: And the glorious lord departed from the city of Kāśī on the sixth and eighth days of the bright fortnight, delighted, with a body fearful to the people of Kāśī, due to the satisfaction of the lord of the universe, the king of debaters.

original: jitvā haiyagavīna madhuripuriva taddeśatejaśca hṛtvā gopībhīteriva smāpasarati lumaḍī bhīmasenānumantā // //
analyzed: jitvā haiyagavīna madhuripuḥ iva tad deśa tejaḥ ca hṛtvā gopī bhīteḥ iva smā apasarati lumaḍī bhīmasena anumantā  /
translated: Having conquered the Hayagrivas and taken away the brilliance of that country like a sweet enemy, the Lumadi, following Bhimasena, retreated as if frightened by the cowherdesses.

original: sārddha śrīvajranāthapaṇḍitasutaiḥ śrīraṅganāthābhidhai rbāhādūrayuvarājasāhanikṛtaiḥ kāśīpraviṣṭaiściram /🔽śrīḍillīśvavāgvilāsarasikairdāmodarai rjyotiṣai rāśīrbhiḥ sa purodhasā raṇabahādūro'viśatsvā purīm // //
analyzed: sārddha śrī vajranātha paṇḍita sutaiḥ śrī raṅganātha abhidhaiḥ bāhādūra yuvarāja sāha nikṛtaiḥ kāśī praviṣṭaiḥ ciram  śrī ḍillī śva vāgvilāsa rasikaiḥ dāmodaraiḥ jyotiṣaiḥ rāśīrbhiḥ sa purodhasā purīm
translated: Along with the sons of the illustrious Vajranatha Pandita, known as Ranganaatha, created by the young prince Bahadura, and those who entered Kashi for a long time,🔽The priest of the illustrious king of Delhi, Damodara, fond of the nectar of speech, along with the astrologers, entered his own city.

original: svasti śrībhadrakālī lumaḍibhagavatī svāmirāja svapālya matvaiva svāgatābhyudgamanasurasikevotthitā tūrṇamāsīt /🔽prāśūdañcadvicitradhvajavasanakṛtollocamullocayantī saddhvānaiḥ kīcakānā mukharitavadanā kṣemakautūhalena // //
analyzed: svasti śrī bhadrakālī lumaḍi bhagavatī svāmi rāja sva pālya matvā eva svāgata abhyudgamana su rasikā iva utthitā tūrṇam āsīt  prāśu udañcat vicitra dhvaja vasana kṛta ullocam ullocayantī sat dhvānaiḥ kīcakānā mukharita vadanā kṣema kautūhalena  /
translated: May there be well-being to the illustrious Bhadrakali, the goddess of Lumadi, the queen of the king, the protector, having considered this, she quickly arose as if delighted by the welcome and rising up.🔽Looking with wide-open eyes at the colorful flags and garments, with her face filled with the sounds of the kettledrums, with curiosity about the well-being.

original: kādambaiḥ patrapuṣpairvikirati pavanoddhūtaśākhāvimuktai rlajjāpīṭhe kadambadru masurabhivane vajratuṇḍīyakṣetre /
analyzed: kādambaiḥ patra puṣpaiḥ vikirati pavana uddhūta śākhā vimuktaiḥ lajjā pīṭhe kadamba dru ma surabhi vane vajratuṇḍīya kṣetre
translated: The wind scatters kadamba flowers with petals and flowers released from the branches shaken by the wind, in the fragrant forest of kadamba trees, the abode of the Vajratunda Yakshas.

original: diṣṭyā bhadra mameti drumagatavayasā rāvatūryapraṇādai rdevī śrībhadrakālī lumaḍibhagavatī vajratuṇḍīsametā // //
analyzed: diṣṭyā bhadra mama iti druma gata vayasā rāva tūrya praṇādaiḥ devī śrī bhadrakālī lumaḍi bhagavatī vajratuṇḍī sametā  /
translated: By good fortune, the goddess Shri Bhadra Kali, the illustrious goddess of Lumpadi, together with Vajra Tundika, is pleased with the sound of conch shells and drums on the tree of old age, saying By good fortune, O Bhadra!

original: capprāsīsainyamadhye vilasati nibhṛta bhīmasenānuyāyī vīraśrīḥ svāmirājo bhujayugaladhṛtoccaṇḍaratnatsarūṇām /
analyzed: capprāsī sainya madhye vilasati nibhṛta bhīmasena anuyāyī vīra śrīḥ svāmi rājaḥ bhuja yugala dhṛta uccaṇḍa ratna tsarūṇām
translated: The king of heroes, the lord of the army, surrounded by the army of Chapra, accompanied by the fearful Bhimasena, holding a pair of arms with a fierce jewel-studded belt,

original: niṣkośānāmasīnā rucibhirupaniṣadrūṣitānekarūpā mūrti bibhratpradadhyāvajananikṛtapūrvā nati bhadrakālyāḥ // //🔽ekāgrīkṛtya citta jalaśayanagata viṣṇumudbodhya vedhā astāvīd yoganidrā madhumukhamasura caṇḍamuṇdau ca hantum /
analyzed: niṣkośā nāma asīnā rucibhiḥ upaniṣad rūṣitā aneka rūpā mūrti bibhrat pradadhyau ajana nikṛta pūrvā nati bhadrakālyāḥ  / ekāgrīkṛtya jalaśayana gata viṣṇum udbodhya vedhāḥ astāvīt yoganidrāḥ madhu mukham asura caṇḍa muṇdau ca hantum
translated: bearing a form tinged with many colors by the rays of the sharp swords and unsheathed weapons, may the form of Bhadra Kali, worshipped by the people, be established.🔽With a concentrated mind, having awakened Vishnu lying on the water bed, Brahma praised the sleep of yoga to kill the demon Madhu and the fierce demon Sunda.

original: hantu pratyagramanyu mahiṣamatha sasainya yatha manyuveśā cchrīsvāmī yogirājo lumuḍibhagavatīstotrakṛt stauti hā smā // //
analyzed: hantu śrī svāmī yogi rājaḥ stauti hā smā
translated: Having killed the buffalo with fresh anger and his army, as if wearing anger, the king of yogis, the lord of the army, the author of the praise of the illustrious goddess of Lumpadi, praises and laments.

original: śrīgaṇeśāya namaḥ /
analyzed: śrī gaṇeśāya namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the illustrious Ganesha.

original: śrīmadaṣṭamātṛbhyo namaḥ /
analyzed: śrīmat aṣṭa mātṛbhyaḥ namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the illustrious eight mothers.

original: svastiśrībhadrakālī lumuḍibhagavatī vajratuṇḍī viśālā brāhmyādyā mātaroṣṭau bhavaduritaharā āstha yūya kṛtajñāḥ /
analyzed: svasti śrī bhadrakālī lumuḍi bhagavatī vajratuṇḍī viśālā brāhmī ādyāḥ mātarā uṣṭau bhava durita harāḥ āstha yūya kṛtajñāḥ
translated: May the eight mothers, Brahma and others, who are auspicious, glorious, black, fierce, the blessed goddess, Vajratuṇḍī, the vast one, who remove the miseries of worldly existence, be pleased and protect me.

original: nepāle puṇyabhūmau nivasatha bhagavatparṣadā sevakoha maryādīkṛtya tanme prakṛtibhavabhaya mocayantu prasannāḥ // //
analyzed: nepāle puṇya bhūmau bhagavat parṣadā maryādīkṛtya tat me prakṛti bhava bhaya mocayantu prasannāḥ  /
translated: Residing in the holy land of Nepal, serving as an attendant of the Blessed One's assembly, may they, being pleased, liberate me from the fear of natural disasters.

original: saṅkaṣṭotpātahantrī bhagavati bhavatī tāriṇī saṅkaṭākhyā āmnāyeṣvapyagamyā prakṛtiṣu vidhurā nāmabhedaikagamyā /🔽padmasthā padmahastā'ntakaturagakaśā durgahā'riṣṭahantrī nepāleśī pumān strī tvamasi kṛtakalidvāparatretayā yuk // //
analyzed: saṅkaṣṭa utpāta hantrī bhagavati bhavatī tāriṇī saṅkaṭa ākhyā āmnāyeṣu api agamyā prakṛtiṣu vidhurā nāma bheda eka gamyā  padma sthā padma hasta antaka turaga kaśā durgaha ariṣṭa hantrī nepāla īśī pumān strī tvam asi kṛta kali dvāpara tretayā yuk  /
translated: O Blessed One, Tārā, who destroys calamities and portents, known as Saṅkaṭā, who is unapproachable even in the scriptures, who is known by the name Vidhurā in the natural states,🔽Residing on a lotus, with lotus in hand, the whip of the horse of death, difficult to overcome, destroying misfortune, the ruler of Nepal, you are a man, a woman, united with the Kali, Dvāpara, and Tretā ages.

original: tva devī vajratuṇḍī tvadadhikṛtiriya bhūmiretarhi tuṇḍī kṣetra lajjopapīṭha janayati viduṣā dhīṣu lajjā kukṛtye /
analyzed: devī vajratuṇḍī tvad adhikṛtiḥ iya bhūmiḥ etarhi tuṇḍī kṣetra lajjā upapīṭha janayati viduṣā dhīṣu lajjā kukṛtye
translated: O Goddess Vajratuṇḍī, this land is under your authority now, the Vajratuṇḍī sacred place generates shame in the minds of the wise regarding evil deeds.

original: siddhairānītakūṭa himaśikharibhava tvatkṛte hyoṣadhīnā tasmāttvā vaidyarājñī prakṛtibhavarujā naumi mūrdhnā natena // //
analyzed: siddhaiḥ ānīta kūṭa hima śikhari bhava tvad kṛte hi oṣadhīnā tasmāt tvā vaidya rājñī prakṛti bhava rujā naumi mūrdhnā natena  /
translated: The siddhas brought the herbs from the peak of the Himalayas for your sake, therefore, I bow my head in homage to you, the queen of medicine, the remover of the pain of natural disasters.

original: śrītuṇḍībhairavastva karakalitakapālaḥ kirīṭī ca daṇḍī tvatpādābjaprasādādatisukhamanubhūta purā rallamallaiḥ /
analyzed: śrī tuṇḍībhairavaḥ tva kara kalita kapālaḥ kirīṭī ca daṇḍī tvad pāda abja prasādāt ati sukham anubhūta purā ralla mallaiḥ
translated: The glorious Tundibhairava, holding a skull in his hand, wearing a crown and a staff, having obtained great happiness in the past through the grace of your lotus feet, O Rallmalla,

original: adyāpi tva mahākāla saphalayati nididhyāsanā putrarājye yasmādakṣobhyamūrtiḥ kṣapayatu durita tva gatistva matirme // //
analyzed: adyā api tva mahākāla saphalayati nididhyāsanā putra rājye yasmāt akṣobhya mūrtiḥ kṣapayatu durita tva gatiḥ tva matiḥ me  /
translated: Even now, O Mahakala, he makes meditation fruitful in the kingdom of his son. May he, whose form is unshakable, destroy my sins and be the goal of my mind.

original: brahmāṇī kanakāvadātavadanā cakrāṅgapṛṣṭhasthitā seve pustakamakṣasūtrakarakā'bhītīrdadhānā karaiḥ /
analyzed: brahmāṇī kanaka avadāta vadanā cakra aṅga pṛṣṭha sthitā seve pustakam akṣasūtra karaka abhītīḥ dadhānā karaiḥ
translated: Brahmani, with a face fair as gold, standing on the back of a tortoise, serving with her hands a book, rosary, and a gesture of protection,

original: cañcatkuṇḍalamaṇḍitā pravilasatsarvāṅgabhūṣojjvalā brahmajñānasamādhigamyaviṣayā brahmāṇi no rakṣatu // //🔽māheśī himakundaśaṅkhadhavalāmudyacchaśāṅkacchavi bheje gopativāhanā trinayanā traiguṇyasantānikām /
analyzed: cañcat kuṇḍala maṇḍitā pravilasat sarva aṅga bhūṣā ujjvalā brahma jñāna samādhi gamya viṣayā brahmāṇi naḥ rakṣatu  / māheśī hima kunda śaṅkha dhavalām udyat śaśāṅka chavi bheje gopativāhanā trinayanā traiguṇya santānikām
translated: Adorned with tinkling earrings, shining with ornaments on all her limbs, may Brahmani, whose object is to be known through the meditation of Brahman's knowledge, protect us.🔽Maheshvari, white as snow, jasmine, and a conch, with the luster of the rising moon, riding on a bull, with three eyes, composed of the three qualities,

original: sṛṣṭyantasthitihetubhūtaniśita dhatte triśūla karai strailokyotkaṭanādanādiḍamaru parśu tathā pāśakam // //
analyzed: dhatte triśūla karaiḥ trailokya utkaṭa nāda nādi ḍamaru parśu tathā pāśakam
translated: She holds a sharp trident in her hands, the cause of creation, preservation, and destruction, and a loud-sounding axe and noose, terrifying the three worlds.

original: śrīkaumāri japāprasūnarudhirābhāse paritrāhi mā bhūyobhirviṣayograpannagaviṣairāghūrṇita durbhagam /
analyzed: śrī kaumāri japā prasūna rudhira ābhāse paritrāhi mā bhūyobhiḥ viṣaya ugra pannaga viṣaiḥ āghūrṇita durbhagam
translated: O Kumari, shining like the red flower of the Japas, protect me again and again from the intoxication of the poison of the fierce serpents.

original: yā reje śṛṇipāśamaṇḍitakarā śaktidhvajau bibhratī vairivrātavidāraṇaikakuśalā māyūrayānasthitā // //
analyzed: yā reje śṛṇi pāśa maṇḍita karā śakti dhvajau bibhratī vairi vrāta vidāraṇa eka kuśalā māyūra yāna sthitā  /
translated: She who shines with hands adorned with a noose and a goad, holding a Shakti and a flag, skilled only in tearing apart hordes of enemies, riding on a peacock.

original: śrīviṣṇormahilā dadhāmi manasā tārkṣyaṅgamā trīkṣaṇā yā dhatte'rigade ca śaṅkhacaṣakau dūrvādalaśyāmalā /
analyzed: śrī viṣṇoḥ mahilā dadhāmi manasā tārkṣī aṅgamā trīkṣaṇā yā dhatte iri gade ca śaṅkha caṣakau dūrvā dala śyāmalā
translated: I mentally hold that woman of Vishnu, with three eyes, who holds a discus, conch, and a cup, dark like a durva leaf.

original: bhaktyudrekajanānuvatsala asanmārgapratidhvasike bhaktānandakari bhavāni tarala sasārapāra naya // //
analyzed: bhakti udreka jana anuvatsala asat mārga pratidhvasike bhakta ānanda kari bhavāni tarala sa sāra pāra naya  /
translated: O one affectionate towards those with abundant devotion, O destroyer of the wrong path, O giver of bliss to devotees, O restless one, lead me to the other shore of existence.

original: śrīndrāṇī kuliśadhvajāṅkitakarā stamberamādhyāsinī dhatte yā'tapava raṇa śṛṇivara kausumbharāgacchaviḥ /
analyzed: śrī indrāṇī kuliśa dhvaja aṅkita karā stamberama adhyāsinī dhatte yāta pava raṇa śṛṇi vara kausumbha rāga chaviḥ
translated: O Indrani, with hands marked by a thunderbolt and a flag, sitting on a clump of grass, who holds a parasol, with a complexion like the color of a red lotus.

original: seya puṣkalabhaktimuktiphaladā śambho bhavatvambikā kṣantavyo'sakṛdeva manturapi me dehi tvadaṅghyrālayam // //
analyzed: sā iya puṣkala bhakti mukti phala dā śambho bhavatu ambikā kṣantavyā usakṛt eva mantuḥ api me dehi tvad aṅghyā ālayam  /
translated: May that Ambika be auspicious to you, O Shambhu, the giver of the fruits of abundant devotion and liberation. You should forgive my frequent repetitions, and grant me the abode of your feet.

original: vārāhī ghanaghorakālavadanā daṣṭroddhṛtakṣmātallā seve sairibhavāhanā paṭuravā khaḍgāṅkuśau bibhratīm /
analyzed: vārāhī ghana ghora kāla vadanā daṣṭra uddhṛta kṣmā tallā seve sairibha vāhanā paṭu ravā khaḍga aṅkuśau bibhratīm
translated: May the Goddess Kali, who has the face of a terrible dark night, who uproots the earth with her tusks, who has a buffalo for her vehicle, who has a loud voice, who holds a sword and goad in her hands,

original: dhatte yogramulūkhala ca muśala dorbhiścaturbhiryutā pāyānmā vikasāruṇā śikhiśikhāpiṅgorddhvakeśāmbikā // //
analyzed: dhatte yā ugram ulūkhala ca muśala dorbhiḥ caturbhiḥ yutā pāyāt mā vikasā aruṇā śikhi śikhā piṅga ūrddhva keśā ambikā
translated: who holds a fierce mortar and pestle, who is endowed with four arms, and whose tawny hair on the head is erect like the crest of a peacock, protect you all.

original: śrīkālī kālarātrī kavalitacaṣakā kālavṛndābhakāyā kakālī kālakarṇī sthapuṭagataśirā muṇḍamālākulāṅgī /🔽yā dhatte'si triśūla kuṇapahṛdi gatā pretabhūmau raṭantī pāyātkālaughakālī phalakayutakarā kādiśīka śaraṇyam // //
analyzed: śrīkālī kālarātrī kavalita caṣakā kāla vṛnda ābha kāyā kakālī kālakarṇī sthapuṭa gata śirāḥ muṇḍa mālā ākula aṅgī  yā kuṇapa hṛdi gatā preta bhūmau raṭantī pāyāt kāla ogha kālī phalaka yuta karā śaraṇyam  /
translated: The Goddess Kali, the night of death, who has swallowed the skull-cup, whose body is like a black cloud, who has black teeth and ears, whose head is covered with a skull, whose body is full of a garland of severed heads,🔽who holds a sword, trident, and skull in her heart, who wanders in the cremation ground making a loud noise, may that Goddess Kali, who has a skull and a sword in her hands, and whose hair is tawny like the crest of a peacock, protect you all.

original: sijannupurapādapadmayugalā karṇojjvalatkuṇḍalā ratnālaṅkṛtibhūṣaṇā'tisubhagā trailokyasarakṣiṇī /
analyzed: karṇa ujjvalat kuṇḍalā ratna alaṅkṛti bhūṣaṇā ati subhagā trailokya sarakṣiṇī
translated: Whose feet are adorned with anklets and toe rings, whose ears shine with earrings, who is adorned with ornaments of jewels, who is extremely beautiful, who protects the three worlds,

original: khaḍgāmbhoruhacarmakharparadharā pañcānanādhyāsinī dāridryānalatāpamutkṣipa jaganmātarmahālakṣmi he // //
analyzed: khaḍga ambhoruha carma kharpara dharā pañcānana adhyāsinī dāridrya anala tāpam utkṣipa jaganmātar mahā lakṣmi he
translated: who holds a sword, lotus, shield, and skull, who sits on a five-headed serpent, O Goddess of great fortune, mother of the world, please remove the burning pain of the fire of poverty.

original: pīyūṣottarapātranirgatasudhādhārābhiṣekocchala jīvaddantyajinokṣabṛhitaparābhūtatrikolīravam /
analyzed: pīyūṣa uttara pātra nirgata sudhā dhārā abhiṣeka ucchala jīvat dantī ajina ukṣa bṛhita parābhūta trikolī ravam
translated: The nectar-like drops flowing from the vessel filled with nectar, the living elephant skin, the sound of the triple conch blown to the highest pitch,

original: vetālorasi saraṭantamasicarmāṅka sudhāśucchaṭā cūḍa trīkṣaṇamūrddhvabarbarakaca seve mahābhairavam // /
analyzed: vetāla urasi sudhā śuc chaṭā cūḍa trīkṣaṇam ūrddhva barbara kaca seve mahābhairavam
translated: The sword and shield moving on the chest of the Vetala, the crest, the three eyes, the upward-streaming matted hair - I worship the great Bhairava.

original: tuṣṭāsvaṣṭasu mātṛkāsu bhavatīṣvaṣṭau mahāsiddhayo ruṣṭāsvaṣṭasu mātṛkābhagavatīṣvaṣṭau mahābhītayaḥ /
analyzed: tuṣṭāsu aṣṭasu mātṛkāsu bhavatīṣu aṣṭau mahāsiddhayaḥ ruṣṭāsu aṣṭasu mātṛkā bhagavatīṣu aṣṭau mahā bhītayaḥ
translated: When the eight mother goddesses are pleased, there are eight great accomplishments; when the eight mother goddesses are angry, there are eight great fears.

original: ye śṛṇvanti paṭhanti caivamurarīkurvanti gṛhṇanti vā teṣā gītamida bhavecciratara śrīsiddhibuddhipradam // //
analyzed: ye śṛṇvanti paṭhanti ca evam urarīkurvanti gṛhṇanti vā teṣām gītam idam bhavet ciratara śrī siddhi buddhi pradam
translated: Those who listen to this, recite it, practice it, or receive it, for them this will be sung for a long time, bestowing the boon of prosperity, accomplishment, and wisdom.

original: ityaṣṭau mātṛkāḥ śrīlumuḍi bhagavati śrīmahākālavīra devi śrīvajratuṇḍi prakṛtibhayahare sakaṭe kaṣṭahantri /
analyzed: iti aṣṭau mātṛkāḥ śrī lumuḍi bhagavati śrī mahākāla vīra devi śrī vajratuṇḍi prakṛti bhaya hare sakaṭe kaṣṭa hantri
translated: Thus, the eight mother goddesses, the glorious Lumudi goddess, the glorious Mahakalavira Devi, the glorious Vajratundi, the remover of natural fear, the destroyer of difficulties,

original: devi pratyaṅgire he bhagavati parakṛtyāvināśaikadakṣe mā me vijñaptimetarhi kuruta ghuṇavarṇaikalakṣā namo vaḥ // //
analyzed: devi pratyaṅgire he bhagavati para kṛtyā vināśa eka dakṣe mā me vijñaptim etarhi kuruta ghuṇa varṇa eka lakṣāḥ namaḥ vaḥ  /
translated: O goddess, O Prthangiras, O Bhagavati, the sole adept in destroying the evil deeds of others, do not disregard my request now. I offer you a lakh of Ghunavarana salutations.

original: sasacivabalavarge svasti gīrvāṇayuddhe diśata sakalasiddhi śrīmahārājarāje /
analyzed: sa saciva bala varge svasti gīrvāṇa yuddhe diśata sakala siddhi śrī mahā rājarāje
translated: May the glorious great king, along with his ministers and army, be well in the battle with the gods.

original: manasi ca parituṣṭe ko'rthavān ko daridra iti bhagavati mātaḥ prārthaye bhaktimekām // //🔽jaya viśvaikavandyeśa jaya nāgendrabhūṣaṇa /
analyzed: manasi ca parituṣṭe korthavān kaḥ daridraḥ iti bhagavati mātar prārthaye bhaktim ekām  / jaya viśva eka vandya īśa jaya nāga indra bhūṣaṇa
translated: When the mind is satisfied, who is wealthy and who is poor? O Goddess, I pray for single-minded devotion to you.🔽Victory to the one who is worshipped by the universe, victory to the ornament of the lord of serpents.

original: jaya gaurīpate śambho jaya candrārddhaśekhara // //
analyzed: jaya gaurīpate śambho jaya candra arddha śekhara
translated: Victory to the lord of Gauri, Shiva, victory to the one with the crescent moon on his head.

original: jaya koṭyarkasakāśa jayānantaguṇāśraya /
analyzed: jaya koṭi arka sakāśa jaya ananta guṇa āśraya
translated: Victory to the one who is like a crore suns, victory to the abode of infinite qualities.

original: jaya rudra virūpākṣa jaya nityanirañjana // //🔽jaya nātha kṛpāsindho jaya bhaktārtibhañjana /
analyzed: jaya rudra virūpākṣa jaya nitya nirañjana  jaya nātha kṛpā sindho jaya bhakta ārti bhañjana
translated: Victory to Rudra, victory to the three-eyed one, victory to the one who is always free from impurities.🔽Victory, O Lord, O ocean of compassion, victory to the destroyer of the distress of devotees.

original: jaya dustarasasārasāgarottāraṇa prabho // //
analyzed: jaya dustara sa sāra sāgara uttāraṇa prabho
translated: Victory, O Lord, to the one who saves from the difficult-to-cross ocean of worldly existence.

original: prasīda me mahākāla sasārātparikheditam /
analyzed: prasīda me mahākāla sa sārāt parikheditam
translated: Be gracious to me, O Great Time, who am exhausted by worldly existence.

original: sarvapāpakṣaya kṛtvā rakṣa mā parameśvara // //
analyzed: sarva pāpa kṣaya kṛtvā rakṣa mā parameśvara
translated: Having destroyed all sins, protect me, O Supreme Lord.

original: tuṣṭā śrībhadrakālī lumuḍibhagavatī vajratuṇḍī viśālā śāntā pratyaṅgirā'kṣobhyamunikṛtaśirasko mahākālavīraḥ /
analyzed: tuṣṭā śrī bhadrakālī lumuḍi bhagavatī vajratuṇḍī viśālā śāntā mahākāla vīraḥ
translated: The auspicious goddess Kali, the revered goddess Lumudi, Vajratundin, Vishala, Shanti, Pratyangira, the great hero Mahakalas, whose heads are made by the sage Akshobhya,

original: hāhāhuhuninādairviyati ghanaghaṭāgarjitairdurdinotthaiḥ sva sva naisargarūpa danujakulavadhe svāmine yattadā'dāt // //
analyzed: hāhā huhu ninādaiḥ viyati ghana ghaṭā garjitaiḥ durdina utthaiḥ sva sva danuja kula vadhe svāmine yat tat ādāt  /
translated: With the sounds of Hā Hā and Hu Hu in the sky, with the thundering of dense clouds arising from the rainy season, the Lord then gave to each of the demon clans their natural forms for the destruction of the demons.

original: datta sabhūya devībhirarikulavadhūbṛndavaidhavyadakṣa rūpa cāstra ca labdhvā nṛpatiraṇabahādūrasāhaḥ pratāpī /
analyzed: devībhiḥ ari kula vadhū bṛnda vaidhavya dakṣa rūpa ca astra ca labdhvā
translated: Having received the weapon of the Goddesses, which is skilled in bestowing widowhood upon the multitude of wives of the enemy clans, the valorous and powerful King Rāṇabāhadura,

original: doṣṇā cākṣṇā sahasra dadhadiva kṛtavīryātmajanmeva śakra śchettā bhettā ripūṇāmapi balisadanādhyāśritānā babhūva // //🔽saudheṣu pramadāpramodhabhaṇite ṣvārabdhagītotsave ṣvāvikṣyan raṇabāhadūranṛpatiryadgopura prākramat /🔽bhūyobhiḥ puravāsinetrajanitaiharṣāśrubhiḥ sākṣatai rgandhaiḥ kṣemakutūhalaplutamukhairbhadrāśiṣā sagataḥ // //
analyzed: doṣṇā ca akṣṇā sahasra dadhat iva kṛtavīrya ātmajanmā iva śakraḥ chettā bhettā ripūṇām api babhūva  / saudheṣu pramadā pramodha bhaṇite su ārabdha gīta utsave su āvikṣyan raṇa bāha dūra nṛpatiḥ yat gopura prākramat  bhūyobhiḥ pura vāsi netra janitaiḥ harṣa aśrubhiḥ sa akṣataiḥ rgandhaiḥ kṣema kutūhala pluta mukhaiḥ bhadra āśiṣā sagataḥ
translated: with his thousand eyes and brows, as if born from the son of Kṛtavīrya, became the cutter and destroyer of even the enemies who had taken refuge in the abode of Bali.🔽When the king Rāṇabāhadura saw the singing festival begun in the words of the watchful women in the mansions,🔽he entered the main gate, accompanied by the auspicious blessings of the multitude of people living in the city, with the tears of joy produced from their eyes, along with the unbroken rice and fragrances, their faces filled with curiosity about his well-being.

original: saudha prāpya jitaśramo raṇabahāduropi sāmarṣaṇaḥ puratnānanapakaja sulalita jighran samāśvāsakaḥ /
analyzed: saudha prāpya jita śramaḥ sa amarṣaṇaḥ jighran samāśvāsakaḥ
translated: Having reached the mansion, Rāṇabāhadura, who had conquered fatigue, was filled with pride. Smelling the very beautiful lotus face of his wife, he comforted her.

original: devī ca tripureśvarī bhagavatī pādābjasavāhinī dṛṣṭvā manyumamūmucacca kanakāvatyutkramottha tvarā // //
analyzed: devī ca tripura īśvarī bhagavatī pāda abja sa vāhinī dṛṣṭvā manyum amūmucat ca kanakāvatī utkrama uttha tvarā
translated: And the goddess Tripura-sundari, the consort of Shiva, seeing the haste of Kanakavati's departure, was filled with anger.

original: devi priye bhāmini cāruśīle diṣṭyā'bhivarddhasva dharātalesmin /
analyzed: devi priye bhāmini cāru śīle diṣṭyā abhivarddhasva dharā tale smin
translated: O Goddess, O Beloved, O Beautiful One, O One of Lovely Character, by good fortune may you prosper on this earth.

original: iti priyālāpanimīlitākṣaḥ premṇānubhūta nijamājagāda // //
analyzed: iti priya ālāpa nimīlita akṣaḥ premṇā anubhūta nijam ājagāda
translated: Thus, with eyes closed by the sweet words of his beloved, he spoke of his own experience out of love.

original: kauśalyeva dharāvaterdaśarathasyārundhatīvad vasi ṣṭhasyarṣeriva jānakī raghupatermeneva śaileśituḥ /
analyzed: kauśalyā iva dharāvateḥ daśarathasya arundhatī vat jānakī raghu pateḥ menā iva śaila īśituḥ
translated: Like the good fortune of Dasharatha, the king of Kosala, like Arundhati of the sage Vasishtha, like Janaki of the lord of the Raghus, like the goddess of the lord of mountains,

original: svāheva jvalanasya śūlina iva śrīviṣṇubhaktiḥ priyā devī sā tripureśvarī raṇabahādūra vyajijñāpayat // //
analyzed: svāhā iva jvalanasya śūlinaḥ iva śrī viṣṇu bhaktiḥ priyā devī sā tripura īśvarī vyajijñāpayat  /
translated: Like the oblation to the fire, like Shri to the trident-holder Shiva, like devotion to Vishnu, the goddess Tripura-sundari, the beloved of Rana-Bahu, made a request.

original: prātīcyatattvamitabhūpagaṇān vijitya prācyairanirjitabhuvo'pi hi sāhadeva /
analyzed: prātīcya tattva mita bhūpa gaṇān vijitya prācyaiḥ anirjita bhuvaḥ api hi sāhadeva
translated: Having conquered the hosts of kings of the western countries, and also those of the eastern countries who had not been conquered by others,

original: kāśyā vihṛtya saphalīkṛtamadya janma kṣātra namo bhagavate'mitavikramāya // //
analyzed: kāśyāḥ vihṛtya saphalīkṛtam adya janma kṣātra namaḥ bhagavatā imita vikramāya  /
translated: Having enjoyed in Kashi, today's birth has become fruitful. O Kshatriya, salutations to the Lord of infinite valor.

original: kroḍīkṛtya suta tato viruruce gīrvāṇayuddha nṛpa śrīsvāmī giriśo yathā gaṇapati pratyarthidāvānalaḥ /
analyzed: kroḍīkṛtya suta tatas viruruce gīrvāṇa yuddha nṛpa śrīsvāmī giriśaḥ yathā gaṇapati pratyarthi dāva analaḥ
translated: Then, embracing his son, he shone like Shiva, the lord of the Gaṇas, in the battle of the gods, the king Shrisvāmin, like a forest fire to the enemies.

original: mūla nirdahadeva kāṇḍamavitā puṣpa phala bṛhaya nnāhosvinnikaṭe phalāyitatarurdūreṇa santāpadaḥ // //
translated: Burning the very root, not the branch, and increasing flowers and fruits, a tree that bears fruit nearby is a source of delight, while one that causes pain is far away.

original: arjyālnāmakapanthaviṣṭaṣaḍakābasnyātathāpāhvayān pāḍeityupanāmakānavitathavyaktārthasabhāṣiṇaḥ /
analyzed: pāḍe iti upanāmakān avitatha vyakta artha sabhāṣiṇaḥ
translated: Having brought together the six teachers named Arjya, Panthavi, Snatha, Apa, Pada, and Upanama, who spoke with true meaning,

original: gorakṣācalanāyakasya nṛpateḥ sannītinirṇāyakān rāṇākhyānatha boharānapi samānāyyākaronnirṇayam // //
analyzed: gorakṣa acala nāyakasya nṛpateḥ sat nīti nirṇāyakān rāṇa ākhyān atha boharān api samānāyya akarot nirṇayam  /
translated: And the judges of the policy of King Gorakshachalanayaka, he also brought together the stories of battles and the Boha, and made a decision.

original: ye kecid vyabhicāriṇaḥ prakṛtiṣu svāmipravāsa bahū kṛtvā mārganirodhinaḥ pratidiśa ye kūṭasacāriṇaḥ /🔽enobhirbahujanmajaiḥ pariṇatā viṇmūtrapūyākule te cāsaskṛtatantubaddhakaṭayo'majjan durantāgasi // //
analyzed: ye kecid vyabhicāriṇaḥ prakṛtiṣu kṛtvā mārga nirodhinaḥ ye kūṭa sacāriṇaḥ  enobhiḥ bahu janma jaiḥ pariṇatāḥ viṣ mūtra pūya ākule te ca asaskṛta tantu baddha kaṭayaḥ majjan duranta āgasi
translated: Those who are unfaithful to their nature, who travel far when the king is away, who obstruct the path in every direction, and who act deceitfully,🔽By these many sins accumulated over many births, they are born in a womb filled with feces, urine, and pus, and their bodies are bound with the strings of karma, they do not escape the great danger of birth and death.

original: cakra nirmāya kāṣṭhodbhavamatha balavad yugyayantrālinaddha grīvāsajja babandha prakṛtiṣu vidhurasyātyaho'runtuda yat /
analyzed: nirmāya kāṣṭha udbhavam atha balavat grīvā sajja babandha prakṛtiṣu vidhurasya ati ahoruntuda yat
translated: Having made a wheel of wood, and having fastened a strong yoke-animal to its neck, he bound it to the nature of the unfortunate one, oh! how painful it is.

original: yasyaikasyāpi vāhadviṣata iva śirodhau hi nistriśadhārā pātaprāya yathā syādahaha raṇabahādūrasāhapratīpāt // //
analyzed: yasya ekasya api vāha dviṣataḥ iva śirodhau hi nistriśa dhārā yathā syāt ahaha
translated: Whose single sword-blade, as if hating the two sides of its own hilt, was about to fall down, alas! from the head of the enemy of Ranabhadra's valor.

original: yā kācit pūtanābhā prakṛtiṣu vidhurā pānakaumārikākhyā kāśīstha svāmirāja vijanamuparaṭanta bahu manyamānā sārddha putreṇa vandīkṛtanijapariṣa dgardabha vāhayānā prāleyādreḥ sutevolvaṇatapa acarattadgireḥ prasthadeśe // //
analyzed: yā kācid pūtanā ābhā prakṛtiṣu vidhurā pānakaumārika ākhyā kāśī stha svāmi rāja vijanam uparaṭanta bahu manyamānā sārddha putreṇa vandīkṛta nija pariṣad gardabha vāhayānā prāleyādreḥ sutā iva ulvaṇa tapa acarat tad gireḥ prastha deśe  /
translated: Whatever she was, a widow in her nature like Putanā, a young girl drinking wine, known as Pānakaumaarikā, living in Kāshi, considering herself very important, with her retinue bowing down to her son, riding on a donkey, like the daughter of the Himalayas, she wandered in the hilly region of that mountain with intense penance.

original: yāstāḥ śūrpaṇakhīkṛtā raṇabahādūreṇa dauvārikāḥ śrīrāmeṇa niśācarīva sahasā cotkṛtta nāsākacāḥ /
analyzed: yāḥ tāḥ śūrpaṇakhī kṛtāḥ raṇa baha adūreṇa dauvārikāḥ śrī rāmeṇa niśācarī iva sahasā ca utkṛtta nāsā kacāḥ
translated: Those who were made like Shurpanakha by Ranabhadra, the doorkeepers, their noses and hair suddenly cut off by Rama, like a demoness.

original: mūrdhnā sarjarasapradīpamadaghātsvāgonurūpa tvarā drohī śaṅkhadharo nayotpathagataśce ṭīprapañcānugaḥ // //
analyzed: mūrdhnā sarja rasa pradīpam adaghāt svāgo nurūpa tvarā drohī śaṅkhadharaḥ naya utpatha gataḥ ce ṭī prapañca anugaḥ
translated: With his head struck by the lamp of resin, his clothes befitting a thief, following the multitude of Cheti, going astray from the path of policy, holding a conch, an enemy.

original: eva ye ya upadrutā raṇabahādūra prati drohiṇa ste sarve'pyabhavan druta hyatithayo vaivasvatasyālaye /
analyzed: eva ye ye upadrutāḥ prati drohiṇaḥ te sarve api abhavan hi atithayaḥ vaivasvatasya ālaye
translated: Those who were thus attacked by Ranabhadra, the enemies, all of them quickly became guests in the abode of Yama.

original: itya śrīraṇabāhadūranṛpatiḥ samardayitvā dviṣo bhīmāyādiśati sma śāśvatapada prasthāpayan kāśikān // //
analyzed: śrī raṇa bāhadūra nṛpatiḥ samardayitvā dviṣaḥ bhīmāya ādiśati sma śāśvata pada prasthāpayan kāśikān
translated: Thus, King Ranabahadur, having defeated the enemies, commands the terrible one to establish the people of Kashi in the eternal abode.

original: adyārabhya madaśamarddhamapi te datta mayā satpada maddharmārddhatanurmadīyacaraṇadhyānaikatāno yataḥ /
analyzed: adyā ārabhya mad aśama ṛddham api te datta mayā sat pada mad dharma arddha tanuḥ madīya caraṇa dhyāna ekatānaḥ yatas
translated: From today onwards, I have given you half of my madness and half of my good position, as you are devoted to meditating on my feet, having half of my Dharma and half of my body.

original: śrīgīrvāṇamahīpatermama sutasyākhaṇḍarāṣṭreṣu bho mantrivyūhaśiromaṇirnṛpahitastva bhīmasenaḥ kṛtī // //
analyzed: śrī gīrvāṇa mahīpateḥ mama sutasya akhaṇḍa rāṣṭreṣu bho mantri vyūha śiromaṇiḥ nṛpa hitaḥ tva bhīmasenaḥ kṛtī  /
translated: O King, you are the crest jewel of the group of ministers of my son, the great king of the gods, in his undivided kingdoms. You are the accomplished Bhimasena, devoted to the king.

original: śrīgīrvāṇamahīpatīndratilakāllabdhaprasādādhikaḥ śrīsvāmī raṇabāhadūra raghupo laṅkā yathā rakṣase /
analyzed: śrī gīrvāṇa mahīpati indra tilakāt labdha prasāda adhikaḥ śrī svāmī raṇa bāha dūra raghupaḥ laṅkāḥ yathā rakṣase
translated: The glorious king of the gods, the crest jewel of the gods, having obtained greater grace from you, the glorious Raghup, the protector of Lanka,

original: kampūnāmasainyasahatimatho savyūhayitvā haṭhā dakṣauhiṇyupamā samarpayati yattadbhīmasenāya ha // //
analyzed: kampū nāma sainya sahatim atho sa vyūhayitvā haṭhā dakṣauhiṇī upamā samarpayati yat tat bhīmasenāya ha
translated: having assembled an army equal to the Kumbha army, and having forcibly united it, he respectfully offers it to Bhimasena.

original: mudrāṇā pātanenā'sakṛdasakṛdabhūddhigulānā mahargha stattallekhyānukūlākṣaratatilikhane kāgadānā maṣīṇām /
analyzed: mudrāṇām pātanena asakṛt asakṛt abhūt hi gulānām maharghaḥ maṣīṇām
translated: By the fall of the seal, the frequent giving of ink for writing the letters favorable to that writing, and the frequent giving of ink for writing the letters favorable to that writing,

original: tattatpatreṣu mārphatsamabhidhalikhane khedatā nāsya jātā jīyānmantrīśathāpākulamaṇiraniśa bhīmaseno yaśasvī // //
analyzed: tad tad patreṣu mārphat samabhidha likhane kheda tā nā asya jātā jīyāt mantrī śathā pākula maṇiḥ aniśa bhīmasenaḥ yaśasvī  /
translated: In writing the various chapters, he did not feel tired. Long live the illustrious Bhimasena, the minister of the king, who is always busy with his jewels.

original: na śāstradṛṣṭyā viduṣā nṛpeṇa vollaṅghanīyāḥ kuladeśadharmāḥ /
analyzed: na śāstra dṛṣṭyā viduṣā nṛpeṇa vā ullaṅghanīyāḥ kula deśa dharmāḥ
translated: The king, who is wise, should not transgress the customs of his family and country, as seen in the scriptures.

original: ityeva vijñāpakabhīmaseno jīyāccira svāmihito yaśasvī // //
analyzed: iti eva vijñāpaka bhīmasenaḥ jīyāt cira svāmi hitaḥ yaśasvī
translated: Thus, may the illustrious Bhimasena, who is afraid of informing, live long, being beneficial to his master.

original: pūrva śrīsvāminā ye viluṭhitamahaso lopitārcā maheśā hārītīśītalādyā digutalitulajābhairavakṣetrapālāḥ /
analyzed: śrī svāminā ye viluṭhita mahasaḥ lopita arcāḥ maheśāḥ hārītī śītala ādyāḥ
translated: Those great lords, Hariti, Sitala and others, the guardians of the Bhairava field, whose great fame was rolled in the dust by the former king, whose worship was erased,

original: te sarve bhīmasenasya hi sacivamaṇeryuktinītiprayogāt svā svāmarcāmavāpurnṛpatiraṇabahādūravākyāhitārcāḥ // //
analyzed: te sarve bhīmasenasya hi saciva maṇeḥ yukti nīti prayogāt svā svām arcām avāpuḥ nṛpati raṇa baha adūra vākya āhita arcāḥ
translated: all of them, by the application of reason and policy of the gem of a minister Bhimasena, regained their own worship, whose worship was harmed by the words of King Hariscandra, who is very brave in battle.

original: ye bhūpāḥ śakrakalpāḥ pramathitapratipakṣā mahotsāhabhājo yeṣā jñānottamānāmapi sacivakula supratispaddhijīvam /
analyzed: ye bhūpāḥ śakra kalpāḥ pramathita pratipakṣāḥ mahā utsāha bhājaḥ jñāna uttamānām api
translated: Those kings, who are like Indra, who have conquered their enemies, who are full of great enthusiasm, whose life is in competition with the family of ministers of the best knowledge,

original: tepyājñālekhyabhūmi druhiṇanarapateḥ śrīhariścandrarājā yadvatsasaktakarmāvalimiha na jahatyatra no citrametat // //
analyzed: druhiṇa narapateḥ śrī hariścandra rājā yadvat sa sakta karma āvalim iha na jahati atra no citram etat  /
translated: they too, like King Hariscandra, the son of Brahma, do not abandon here the series of duties they are engaged in, this is not surprising.

original: abdhinulladhayanti pratidiśamanuyāntyāruhantyadrikūṭān kāntārāṇyāviśanti kṣititalamanugacchanti karmāṇi nūnam /
analyzed: pratidiśam anuyānti āruhanti adri kūṭān kāntārāṇi āviśanti kṣiti talam anugacchanti karmāṇi nūnam
translated: They cross the oceans, follow in all directions, climb mountain peaks, enter the wilderness, follow the earth, and surely follow their own actions.

original: pātāla cāviśantyūrmaya iva payasā prāktanānā ca yeṣā yāvadbhuktarna lokābhyanugamanavidhau mārgaroddhā na kaścit // //
analyzed: ca āviśanti ūrmayaḥ iva payasā ca loka abhyanugamana vidhau mārga roddhā na kaścid
translated: They enter the netherworld like waves in the water, and as long as they have not enjoyed the fruits of their past actions, there is no one to show them the path.

original: sā dīrghā karmavallī satatamabhinavā yā purāṇaiḥ phalaughai rvyāptā sāścaryarūpā satatamanugatā dehinā niścalā ca /
analyzed: sā dīrghā karma vallī satatam abhinavā yā purāṇaiḥ phala oghaiḥ vyāptā sa āścarya rūpā satatam anugatā dehinā niścalā ca
translated: That long creeper of action, which is always new with a stream of old fruits, which is covered with wonderful forms, which is always followed by embodied beings without moving,

original: yā cākṛṣṭopaviṣṭā tadanu vighaṭitotpāṭitā moṭitā vā naikaiḥ puṇyaiḥ susūkṣma kaṇaśa api kṛtā naiva yāti kṣaya yā // //
analyzed: yā ca ākṛṣṭa upaviṣṭā tadanu vighaṭita utpāṭitā moṭitā vā na ekaiḥ puṇyaiḥ api kṛtā na eva yāti kṣaya yā
translated: Which is drawn out and seated, then torn apart, uprooted, and crushed by many merits, even if made into very fine particles, does not perish at all.

original: kānte kāye yadindurvahati ca malina doṣavimba garīyaḥ krurākāro bhujaṅgaḥ kiraṇasujaṭila yanmaṇi kṛṣṇasarpaḥ /
analyzed: kānte kāye yat induḥ vahati ca malina doṣa vimba garīyaḥ krura ākāraḥ bhujaṅgaḥ kiraṇa su jaṭila yat maṇi kṛṣṇa sarpaḥ
translated: If the moon resides in the beloved body, and if a black snake with a fierce form and heavy, dirty disc-like spots is coiled in the well-arranged jewels,

original: nānārūpaiśca kirmīracaritamaniśa bhūbhṛtā darśayantī seya citrakramālīpariṇatibahulā karmanirmāṇarekhā // //
analyzed: nānā rūpaiḥ ca kirmīra caritam aniśa bhūbhṛtā darśayantī sā iya citrakra mālī pariṇati bahulā karma nirmāṇa rekhā
translated: And if it always shows various forms and activities of the serpent-like mountains, then this is the line of creation of action, with many changes in the sequence of colors.

original: citraguptaviṣayīkṛtasāro dharmarāja abhitaḥ smararāja /
analyzed: citragupta viṣayīkṛta sāraḥ dharmarāja abhitas smararāja
translated: The essence of the subject matter of Chitragupta, the king of Dharma, is remembered all around.

original: bhīmasenaviṣayīkṛtabhāraḥ svāmirāja abhito'pararāja // //
analyzed: bhīmasena viṣayīkṛta bhāraḥ svāmi rājaḥ abhitopararāja
translated: The burden of Bhimasena is remembered all around by the king of kings.

original: tribhuvanabhuvanodareṣu bhāvī phalati hi jantuṣu karmaṇā vipākaḥ /
analyzed: tribhuvana bhuvana udareṣu bhāvī phalati hi jantuṣu karmaṇā vipākaḥ
translated: In the wombs of the three worlds, the fruit of karma ripens for living beings.

original: kva ca nṛparaṇabāhadūrasāhaḥ kva ca sahajāhitaserabāhadūraḥ // //
analyzed: kva ca nṛpa raṇa bāha dūra sāhaḥ kva ca sahaja ahitasera bāha dūraḥ
translated: Where is the king Parana Bahadursaha, and where is the naturally harmful Seera Bahadursaha?

original: snāyī gāṅgeṣu vārṣu kṣitiparaṇabahādurasāhaḥ sahāṅga śrīmadgīrvāṇayuddha prakṛtiṣu sarale bhīmasene'rpayitvā /
analyzed: snāyī gāṅgeṣu vārṣu saha aṅga śrīmat gīrvāṇa yuddha prakṛtiṣu sarale bhīmasena īrpayitvā
translated: Having entrusted the beautiful Bhima to the natural enemies in the battles of the gods, the king Parana Bahadursaha, having bathed in the waters of the Ganges,

original: dvandvatīta prapede padamamalamala svāśrayasyopariṣṭāt svāmyājñā pālayitvā jayati nṛpahito bhīmaseno yaśasvī // //
analyzed: dvandva tīta prapede padam amala mala sva āśrayasya upariṣṭāt svāmi ājñā pālayitvā jayati nṛpa hitaḥ bhīmasenaḥ yaśasvī  /
translated: having protected the command of the king, the famous Bhimasena, who has gone beyond duality, shines, having attained the stainless state above his own abode.

original: rājā pālpīyo vidursāhasera bāhādūrsāhopyamātyo nṛsihaḥ /
analyzed: rājā vidursāhasera
translated: The king is known as Palpiya, the minister as Bahadursaha, and the king as Nrisimha.

original: dāmnaikenānītavanto niṣādai rullūnāste karmaṇe vai namo'stu // //
analyzed: dāmnā ekena ānītavantaḥ niṣādaiḥ rullūnāḥ te karmaṇe vai namaḥ astu
translated: They were brought by the fishermen with a single rope and cut off. Salutations to that action!

original: śrīsvāmidrohiṇo ye dharaṇipaparicaryāpratīpāḥ parokṣā ullūnāste viluṇṭhadvibhavaparijanāḥ pulkaśānītatīrthāḥ /
analyzed: śrī svāmi drohiṇaḥ ye dharaṇipa paricaryā pratīpāḥ parokṣāḥ ullūnāḥ te viluṇṭhat vibhava parijanāḥ pulkasa ānīta tīrthāḥ
translated: Those who are enemies of Lord Shiva, averse to serving the earth, cut off indirectly, with their wealth and relatives plundered, brought to the tirtha by the Pulkasas,

original: āsurdātyūhadākṣāyyavṛkabhaṣakagomāyusavāhitāṅgāḥ śryabde'gnyaṅgāṣṭarūpe hyahaha sukṛtino ye'vaśiṣṭāḥ kṛtajñāḥ // //
analyzed: āsuḥ dātyūha dākṣāyya vṛka bhaṣaka gomāyu sava āhita aṅgāḥ hi ahaha su kṛtinaḥ kṛtajñāḥ  /
translated: Those whose bodies are possessed by the spirits of Asuras, Dātyūhas, Dākṣāyaṇas, wolves, jackals, and hyenas, and those who are left, who are grateful, in the eight forms of Śrī, Agni, and Aṅga, are indeed the virtuous ones.

original: rājñī śrīrājyalakṣmīḥ kaṭaharavipinātprākkramitvaiva pūrva diṣṭyā lāmāgurūṇā paricaraṇavaśādakṣamālā japantī /
analyzed: rājñī śrī rājya lakṣmīḥ kaṭahara vipināt prāk kramitvā eva diṣṭyā paricaraṇa vaśāt akṣamālāḥ japantī
translated: The queen, Śrī Rājyalakṣmī, having first gone from the forest of Kaṭahararavi, by the power of serving the elders of the Lāma sect, chanting the rosary of prayers,

original: prāleyādreḥ sutevoparigaganatalātprākkramitvā hirabu sthānādanvagyayau śrīpaśupa raṇabahādūramāsaptamāhāt // //
analyzed: prāleyādreḥ sutā iva upari gagana talāt prāk kramitvā sthānāt anvagyayau śrī paśupa
translated: Having first gone from the daughter of the Himālaya mountain, from the upper sky, from the place of Hiraṇyagarbha, she followed Śrī Paśupateśvara, the son of Rāṇā Bāhadūra.

original: gulmī janmasthala tatpatirapi janakaḥ kṣātradharmeṣu gaṇyo yasyā bhartā ca gorṣāpatiṣu parivṛḍho mallajetuśca naptā /
analyzed: gulmī tad patiḥ api janakaḥ kṣātra dharmeṣu gaṇyaḥ yasyāḥ bhartā ca gorṣā patiṣu parivṛḍhaḥ malla jetuḥ ca naptā
translated: She whose birthplace is Gulmi, whose father is also worthy among the Kṣatriyas, whose husband is the lord of the Gaurṣāpati kings, and the grandson of the conqueror of the Malla kings,

original: nāmnā śrīrājyalakṣmīḥ kaṭaharavipina prāpya kāśīmagatvā anvārohaccitā śrīkṣitiparaṇabahādūramāsaptamāhāt // //
analyzed: nāmnā śrī rājya lakṣmīḥ prāpya kāśīm a gatvā anvārohat citā
translated: By the name Śrī Rājyalakṣmī, having reached Kāśī from the forest of Kaṭahararavi, and having ascended the funeral pyre, followed Śrī Kṣitipa Rāṇā Bāhadūra, the son of the seventh.

original: ittha śrīraṇabāhadūracirita sakṣipya savarṇita ye śṛṇvantyavadhārayanti mahasā gorakṣabhūpādbhutam /
analyzed: ittha sa kṣipya sa varṇita ye śṛṇvanti avadhārayanti mahasā gorakṣa bhūpa adbhutam
translated: Those who, having briefly heard and understood in this way the wonderful greatness of King Gorakṣa, as told by Śrī Rāṇā Bāhadūra,

original: teṣā vigrahapratyavāyajanita lokeṣu saśāmyate /
analyzed: teṣām vigraha pratyavāya janita lokeṣu
translated: Their disputes and obstacles are pacified in the world.

original: śrīratnatrayasabhava sukhakara jñāna dhana jāyate // //
analyzed: śrī ratnatraya sabhava sukha kara jñāna dhana jāyate
translated: The abode of the three jewels, the giver of happiness, the wealth of knowledge is born.

original: iti prathama prakṛtiratnam śrīgaṇeśāya namaḥ //
analyzed: iti prathama prakṛti ratnam śrī gaṇeśāya namaḥ
translated: Thus ends the first chapter on the jewel of nature. Salutations to the illustrious Ganesha.

original: nūvākoṭavihāriṇātha mṛgayālubdhena tuṣṭena vai sarva bhīmamaya jagatkṛtavatā gīrvāṇayuddhena yā /
analyzed: mṛgayā lubdhena tuṣṭena vai bhīma maya jagat kṛtavatā gīrvāṇa yuddhena yā
translated: By the contented and greedy hunter who roams in the crores of worlds, who made the entire world full of fear, with the war of the gods,

original: vīrāṇāmapi bhītidā janaraletyākhyā kṛtvā tasya yā sa pratyagramajāgarītkṣititale pratyekatajaḥpradā // //
analyzed: vīrāṇām api bhīti dā janaralā iti ākhyā kṛtvā tasya yā sa pratyagram ajāgarīt kṣiti tale
translated: Who, having given the name Janarala which strikes fear even in the brave, he who was born on the earth with a fresh goat,

original: śrīpṛthvinārāyaṇasāhadevanaptrātmajo dāśarathiḥ sma yena /
analyzed: śrī pṛthvi nārāyaṇa sāhadeva naptṛ ātmajaḥ dāśarathiḥ sma yena
translated: The son of Dasharatha, who was born from the grandson of King Prithvinarayanasahadeva,

original: abhūtapūrvo niramāyi seturbhīmānumatyā'rpitasihaketuḥ // //
analyzed: abhūta pūrvaḥ niramāyi setuḥ bhīma anumatyā arpita siha ketuḥ  /
translated: By whom an unprecedented bridge was built, with a lion-banner offered by the fearful Anumati.

original: yatsihaketorvivṛtāsyakūṭa vilokya pārasthahanūmatāpi /
analyzed: yat siha ketoḥ vivṛta āsya kūṭa vilokya pāra stha hanūmatā api
translated: Even by Hanuman, who saw the peak of the open mouth of Sihaketu on the other side,

original: tṛptyai dadhikṣīraghṛtekṣuśākānyupājihīte krayikacchalena // //
analyzed: tṛptyai dadhi kṣīra ghṛta ikṣu śākāni upājihīte krayika chalena
translated: He pretended to be a buyer and collected curd, milk, ghee, sugarcane and vegetables for satisfaction.

original: hanūmato'pīpsitamākalayya yūpasthasihaḥ karamunnamayya /
analyzed: hanūmatā upi īpsitam ākalayya yūpa stha sihaḥ karam unnamayya
translated: Sihaketu, seeing what was desired even by Hanuman, raised his hand on the sacrificial post,

original: kṛtārthatā vedayatīva tasya siho hanūmānapi pānthamavyāt // //🔽yatsihaketormukhagopurādvai kapotapārāvatasārikādīn /
analyzed: kṛtārtha tā vedayati iva tasya sihaḥ hanūmān api pāntham avyāt    yat sihaketoḥ mukha gopurāt vai kapota pārāvata sārikā ādīn
translated: The lion and Hanuman, as if to announce his success, protected the traveler.

original: meruḥ svakūṭādiva khecaraudhānamūmucadbhūpanibaddhayūpaḥ // //
analyzed: meruḥ sva kūṭāt iva khecaraudhānam ūmucat bhūpa nibaddha yūpaḥ
translated: From the lion-bannered one's mouth-fortress, the Meru mountain, as if bound to an altar by the king, released pigeons, doves, parrots, and others, as if they were aerial vehicles from its peak.

original: gīrvāṇayuddhādhipadattapūja śrīsvāmigañja ramaṇīyakuñjam /
analyzed: gīrvāṇa yuddha adhipa datta pūja śrī svāmi gañja ramaṇīya kuñjam
translated: The beautiful grove of the glorious lord of the heaven-dwellers, worshipped by the lord of the gods,

original: tīrapratīre saritā varāyāḥ prakṣiptagulmadru mabhūribījam // //🔽janāśrayaiścārutaraiḥ suramya bālābalāvṛddhajanaikagamyam /🔽viśālavātāyanaśālaharmya vitardiniryūhavisṛṣṭanīḍam // //
analyzed: tīra pratīre saritā varāyāḥ prakṣipta gulma dru ma bhūri bījam  jana āśrayaiḥ cārutaraiḥ su ramya bāla abalā vṛddha jana eka gamyam  viśāla vātāyana śāla harmya vitardi niryūha visṛṣṭa nīḍam
translated: with abundant seeds of creepers and trees thrown on both banks of the best river.🔽Very beautiful with the most charming abodes of people, accessible only to young, old, and middle-aged people,🔽with spacious windows, halls, terraces, and balconies, with nests provided,

original: kapotapālīpariṇaddhagopānasīvicitrīkṛtaputtalīkam /
analyzed: kapota pālī pariṇaddha gopānasī vicitrīkṛta puttalīkam
translated: with the roofs adorned with pigeon-nests,

original: pravāsibhirlabdhasadāvṛtīka stheyāttadābhūmikamavyalīkam // //
analyzed: pravāsibhiḥ labdha sat āvṛtīka stheyāt tat ābhūmikam avyalīkam
translated: the earth should be inhabited by the king, who has always obtained protection from the people, without deceit.

original: ityevamāsādayadāsa bhūpo gīrvāṇayuddho nṛpamaṇḍalīśaḥ /🔽sa śītalācāranidarśanena śuddhāntacorī bibharāmbabhūva // //
analyzed: iti evam āsādayat āsa bhūpaḥ gīrvāṇa yuddhaḥ nṛpa maṇḍala īśaḥ  sa śītala ācāra nidarśanena śuddhānta corī bibharāmbabhūva
translated: Thus did King Ulloca, the lord of the circle of kings, obtain.🔽He, with the example of cool conduct, became the thief in the inner apartments, bearing the pure.

original: pataṅgamullocayadāsa bhūpo gīrvāṇayuddhaḥ sa ca bhīmasenaḥ /
analyzed: pataṅgam ullocaya dāsa bhūpaḥ gīrvāṇa yuddhaḥ sa ca bhīmasenaḥ
translated: King Ulloca, the heaven-dweller, and he Bhimasena,

original: svatantunā kalkavilepitena paura pataṅga gaganād babādhe // //🔽sa bhīmasenena kṛtādareṇa paura pataṅgāhṛtiluptadhairyam /
analyzed: sva tantunā kalka vilepitena paura pataṅga gaganāt babādhe  / sa bhīmasenena kṛta ādareṇa paura pataṅga āhṛti lupta dhairyam
translated: With his own thread smeared with chalk, he tormented the citizens like a moth from the sky.🔽He, whose patience was lost due to the removal of the citizens by Bhimasena, who was honored by him,

original: vinodayan dattadhanaḥ svageha prasthāpayāmāsa nṛpaḥ sa dhanyaḥ // //
analyzed: vinodayan datta dhanaḥ sva geha prasthāpayāmāsa nṛpaḥ sa dhanyaḥ  /
translated: The blessed king, having given wealth, sent him to his own house for amusement.

original: śrīmadgīrvāṇayuddhāccyutakarakamalollocayan satpataṅgo viṣṇornābhīsarojodbhava iva parameṣṭyantarīkṣe vireje /
analyzed: śrīmat gīrvāṇa yuddhāt cyuta kara kamala ullocayan sat pataṅgaḥ viṣṇoḥ nābhī saroja udbhavaḥ iva parameṣṭi antarīkṣe vireje
translated: The good moth, opening its eyes like the lotus of Vishnu's navel, shone in the highest sky, as if born from the lotus of Vishnu's navel.🔽Having stayed in the house of Tulja, with the name Shri Taluju, along with Bhimasena,

original: sthitvā tuljālaye śrītalijusamabhidhe bhīmasenena sārddha thāpāratnena tantugrahaṇapaṭudhiyā lakṣadṛṣṭyā nipītaḥ // //🔽śrīmadgīrvāṇayuddhāgrimanṛpatiyaśaḥkṣīradhau koṭanāmā ḍiṇḍīraḥ prādurāsīddhanumata anubhāvād yathā bhīmayatnāt /
analyzed: sthitvā tulja ālaye śrī taliju samabhidhe bhīmasenena sārddha thāpāratnena tantu grahaṇa paṭu dhiyā lakṣa dṛṣṭyā nipītaḥ  / śrīmat gīrvāṇa yuddha agrima nṛpati yaśaḥ kṣīradhau koṭa nāmā ḍiṇḍīraḥ prādurāsīt hanumata anubhāvāt yathā bhīma yatnāt
translated: the king, skilled in grasping the thread with his sharp eyes, was drunk by Lakshmana.🔽The king named Koti, the churned milk of the fame of the foremost king in the battle of the glorious gods, appeared like a Dindira, by the power of Hanuman, with great effort.

original: mainākaḥ pakṣarakṣāpara iva dharaṇīpālamallapratīpād dhvasībhūtaḥ purā śrīnṛpatiraṇabahādūrajaḥ sa sma dhanyaḥ // //
analyzed: mainākaḥ pakṣa rakṣā paraḥ iva dharaṇī pāla malla pratīpāt dhvasībhūtaḥ purā sa sma dhanyaḥ  /
translated: The blessed one, born from the glorious king Nripati Bahadur, like Mainaka, as if intent on protecting the wings of the king of the earth, became famous in the past.

original: śrīgīrvāṇamahīpatirjanaralaḥ śrībhīmasenaśca tau jāgratsvapnasuṣuptiṣu pratipada prītau jaratkāruvat /🔽śrīrājendramahīpati svatanuja vinyasya tasyādare śakra jetumiyādabhartyabhavana yacchītalānoditaḥ // //
analyzed: śrī gīrvāṇa mahīpatiḥ jana ralaḥ śrī bhīmasenaḥ ca tau jāgrat svapna suṣuptiṣu pratipada prītau jaratkāru vat  śrī rāja indra mahīpati sva tanuja vinyasya tasya ādare śakra jetum iyāt abhartya bhavana yat śītala ānoditaḥ  /
translated: The king of the gods, Indra, and the great king Bhima, both of whom are always devoted to Jaratkaru, like in the states of waking, dreaming, and deep sleep,🔽The king of kings, Rajendra, having placed his son in charge of his kingdom, went to conquer the abode of Indra, being cool and composed.

original: śrīmadgīrvāṇayuddhakṣitipaparivṛḍhādantarā labdharājyaḥ samrāḍāvirbabhūva kṣitipatitilako rājarājendrasāhaḥ /
analyzed: śrīmat gīrvāṇa yuddha kṣitipa parivṛḍhāt antarā labdha rājyaḥ samrāj āvirbabhūva kṣitipati tilakaḥ rājarāja indra sāhaḥ
translated: The emperor, having obtained the kingdom from the king of the gods, the lord of the earth, appeared as the crest jewel of kings.

original: śāke'gnyadryaṣṭarūpe paśupaticaraṇoddhū tadhūlīvitānai rallairmallaiḥ pratiṣṭhīkṛtanṛpasadane vaijayantī cakāra // //
analyzed: śākegnī adri aṣṭa rūpe paśupati caraṇa uddhū ta dhūlī vitānaiḥ rallaiḥ mallaiḥ pratiṣṭhīkṛta nṛpa sadane vaijayantī cakāra  /
translated: In the Saka year 800, in the month of Ashvini, in the house of King Nripati, which was established by the Malla kings, he hoisted the victory banner.

original: kṛṣṇa yaśodeva rarakṣa yeya rājendrasāha kṣitipālaratnam /🔽seya trivargaprakṛtiḥ sudhanyā lalittripursundarikā sma reje // //
analyzed: kṛṣṇa yaśodeva rarakṣa rāja indra sāha kṣitipāla ratnam  sā iya trivarga prakṛtiḥ su dhanyā lalit tripur sundarikā sma reje
translated: Krishna, the king of kings, Rajendra, the jewel among kings, protected her.🔽She, the nature of the three goals, was very fortunate, and the beautiful Sundarika of Tripura shone.

original: dhanyā śrīśubhavarṇapuṣkalatayā svargāvatīrṇā śacī devīva tripureśvarī vasumatī devī varīvarti sā /
analyzed: dhanyā śrī śubha varṇa puṣkala tayā svarga avatīrṇā śacī devī iva tripura īśvarī vasumatī devī varīvarti sā
translated: The fortunate Shachi, descended from heaven with an excellent complexion like that of Shri, the goddess of the three cities, the goddess of the earth, remained.

original: seya śrītripureśvara raṇabahādūraprakṛtyā'rabhat tīrthe puṇyatame saniṣkuṭamahāprāsādasatrālayam // //
analyzed: śrī tripureśvara raṇa baha adūra prakṛtyā ārabhat tīrthe puṇyatame sa niṣkuṭa mahā prāsāda satra ālayam
translated: That Shri Tripureshwari, with the nature of Ranabahadur, began in the most sacred of holy places, a palace with a large courtyard, a sacrificial hall.

original: hāhāhūhupurogamāśca vasavaḥ kāṣṭhādhipāśceṣṭadā viśvedevapurogamāśca tuṣitā ābhāsvarāḥ sānilāḥ /
analyzed: hāhā hūhu purogamāḥ ca vasavaḥ kāṣṭha adhipāḥ ca iṣṭa dāḥ viśvedeva purogamāḥ ca tuṣitāḥ ābhāsvarāḥ sa anilāḥ
translated: The Vasus led by Haha and Huhu, the lords of the quarters granting wishes, the Vishvadevas led by the Tushitas, the Abhasvaras with the wind-god,

original: sarve dasrapurogamāśca saha taiḥ śrīviśvakarmā'cirā cchrīmatsvāmyupaveśanārthamagamat prāsādasasiddhaye // //
analyzed: sarve dasra purogamāḥ ca saha taiḥ śrī viśvakarmā acirāt śrīmat svāmi upaveśana artham agamat prāsāda sa siddhaye
translated: All led by the Ashvins, along with them, the illustrious Vishvakarma soon went to the holy place to accomplish the construction of the palace for the installation of the illustrious Lord.

original: eva śrītripureśvarī bhagavatī nirmāpayitvādarād devāgāramupaskareṇa sahita ghaṇṭātriśūlādibhiḥ /
analyzed: eva śrī tripureśvarī bhagavatī nirmāpayitvā ādarāt devāgāram upaskareṇa ghaṇṭā triśūla ādibhiḥ
translated: Thus, the illustrious Goddess Tripureshwari, having respectfully constructed the temple of the Lord along with the necessary articles, bells, tridents, etc.,

original: tīrtha kālavimocanābhidhamadhi prapyārpayacchūline khyāto'stu tripureśvaro'yamavanau durbhikṣakaṣṭādihā // //
analyzed: tīrtha kālavimocana abhidham adhi prapyārpayat śūline khyātoḥ tu tripureśvaraḥ yam avanau durbhikṣa kaṣṭa ādihā
translated: Having reached the holy place called Kalavimocana, offered it to the Trident-bearer. May this Tripureshwara be famous on earth, removing famine, distress, etc.

original: śrīdevyuvāca /
analyzed: śrī devī uvāca
translated: The Goddess said:

original: purāṇāntare dhyāyennitya maheśa rajatagirinibha cārucandrāvatasa ratnākalpojjvalāṅga paraśumṛgavarābhītihasta prasannam /
analyzed: purāṇa antare dhyāyet nitya maheśa rajata giri nibha cāru candra avatasa ratna ākalpa ujjvala aṅga paraśu mṛga vara abhīti hasta prasannam
translated: In another Purana, one should always meditate on Maheshvara, who is like a silver mountain, has a beautiful moon on his forehead, whose body shines like jewels, who holds an axe, a deer, an excellent boon, and a gesture of protection in his hands, and is serene,

original: padmāsīna samantātstutamamaragaṇairvyāghrakṛtti vasāna viśvādya viśvadandya nikhilabhayahara pañcavaktra trinetram // //
analyzed: padma āsīna samantāt stutam amara gaṇaiḥ vyāghra kṛtti vasāna viśva adya viśva dandya nikhila bhaya hara pañcavaktra trinetram
translated: Seated on a lotus, praised all around by the hosts of immortals, wearing a tiger skin, the beginning and end of the universe, the remover of all fears, five-faced, three-eyed,

original: kīṭairjuṣṭamamedhyabhūpariṇata vastrāñcalasparśi yat paryuṣṭa gaṇarātramāgamaniṣiddha puṣpamapyarpitam /
analyzed: kīṭaiḥ juṣṭam amedhya bhū pariṇata vastra añcala sparśi yat puṣpam api arpitam
translated: Touched by the hem of clothes fallen on impure ground infested with insects, offered flowers prohibited by the rules of conduct,

original: no jāne bhavadīyasevanavidhi prāmādika kevala bhūyastvena kṛpālunā bhagavatā kṣantavyamāgo mama // //
analyzed: no jāne bhavadīya sevana vidhi prāmādika bhūyastvena kṛpālunā bhagavatā kṣantavya māgaḥ mama
translated: I do not know if the method of serving you was due to negligence alone. O merciful one, you should forgive my faults.

original: yaddatta bhaktipūrva kusumaphalajala gandhavastropavīta dīpa naivedyamanna punarapi madhuparka punaḥ pādyamardhyam /
analyzed: bhakti pūrva kusuma phala jala gandha vastra upavīta dīpa naivedya manna punar api madhuparka punar pādyam ardhyam
translated: The flowers, fruits, water, incense, garments, sacred thread, lamps, food offerings, and again the madhuparka and water for washing the feet and the respectful offering, which were offered with devotion,

original: mantreṇonādhikārṇena ca japitamaho cetasā tāmasena tannyūnādhikyadoṣa mama hara sakala tubhyamevārpayāmi // //
analyzed: mantreṇa ūna adhika arṇena ca japitam aho cetasā tāmasena tad nyūna ādhikya doṣa mama hara sakala tubhyam eva arpayāmi  /
translated: Recited with mantras of incomplete or extra syllables, and with a dull mind, I offer all that to you, O Lord, please remove the faults of incompleteness or excess.

original: dhyāyan dhyāyan dharaṇipamaha cetasā nirmameṇa pāyan pāyan caraṇajasudhā karmaṇā sādareṇa /
analyzed: dhyāyan dhyāyan dharaṇipam aha cetasā nirmameṇa pāyan pāyan caraṇa ja sudhā karmaṇā sādareṇa
translated: Meditating again and again on the earth with a pure mind, drinking again and again the nectar from the feet with respectful action,

original: smāran smāran sunṛtamanasā bhūtapa sāhadeva bhūyo bhūyo hṛdayakamale bhāvaye'ha bhavantam // //
analyzed: smāran smāran su nṛta manasā bhūtapa sāhadeva bhūyas bhūyas hṛdaya kamale bhāvaya iha bhavantam  /
translated: Remembering, remembering with a pure mind, O son of Kunti, I shall again and again contemplate on you, O Bhava, in the lotus of my heart.

original: tvamasi bhavapāvako mama kaluṣadāhakaḥ pramathagaṇanāyako bhavajaladhitārakaḥ /
analyzed: tvam asi bhava pāvakaḥ mama kaluṣa dāhakaḥ pramatha gaṇa nāyakaḥ bhava jaladhi tārakaḥ
translated: You are the fire that burns the miseries of worldly existence, the one who burns away my sins, the leader of the Pramathas, the one who rescues from the ocean of worldly existence.

original: diviṣadanuṣaṅgakastvamasi harisevaka stvamasi haripālako vihitavidhikautukaḥ // //
analyzed: diviṣad anuṣaṅgakaḥ tvam asi hari sevakaḥ stvam asi hari pālakaḥ vihita vidhi kautukaḥ
translated: You are the one who is attached to the gods, the servant of Hari, the protector of Hari, the one who delights in performing rituals.

original: akulajanibālako nikhilayugavārddhakaḥ sasuranararañcako vividhanidhidarśakaḥ /
translated: You are the one who protects the unborn child, the one who is in the prime of youth for all the yugas, the one who delights the gods and men, the one who shows various treasures.

original: avatu bhavadarbhaka dharaṇipatibālaka suciratarajīvaka haratu tadariṣṭakam // //🔽etādṛṅmukhavādyavādanaparā hṛṣṭā pragalbhā satī āyuḥprārthanayā cirāya nṛpate rājendrarājeśituḥ /
analyzed: avatu bhavat arbhaka dharaṇi pati bālaka suciratara jīvaka haratu tat ariṣṭakam  etādṛś mukha vādya vādana parā hṛṣṭā pragalbhā satī āyuḥ prārthanayā cirāya nṛpate rāja indra rāja īśituḥ
translated: May you protect the child of the king of the earth, the one who lives for a very long time, may you remove all his misfortunes.🔽The bold and delighted chaste woman, engaged in playing the musical instruments with such a face, for a long time, by requesting for longevity of the king, the lord of the kings of kings.

original: śiñjadbhūṣaṇakaṅkaṇādivalayottālāvarodhāvṛtā devī śrīlalitatripursamabhidhā śrīsundarī rājate // //
analyzed: śiñjat bhūṣaṇa kaṅkaṇa ādi valaya uttāla avarodha āvṛtā devī śrī lalitatripuḥ samabhidhā śrī sundarī rājate  /
translated: Surrounded by the loud women adorned with jingling ornaments, bangles, and bracelets, the goddess Shri Lalita Tripura Sundari shines.

original: eva śrītripureśvara smarati yaḥ stoṣyatyanuṣṭhīyate rājāmātyapurodhasā hitataraḥ sajāyate niścitam /
analyzed: eva śrī tripureśvara smarati yaḥ stoṣyati anuṣṭhīyate rāja amātya purodhasā hitataraḥ sajāyate niścitam
translated: Thus, he who remembers, praises, and practices the praise of the Lord of Tripura, becomes most beneficial to the king, ministers, and priests, for certain.

original: stotuḥ śrotururīkṛtasya paṭhataḥ pratyūhadāvānala rājño'gneḥ paripanthino'pyapamṛteścorācca na syādbhayam // //
analyzed: stotuḥ śrotuḥ urīkṛtasya paṭhataḥ pratyūha dāva anala rājñaḥ agneḥ paripanthinaḥ api apamṛteḥ corāt ca na syāt bhayam  /
translated: For the praiser, listener, reciter, and reader, there will be no fear from obstacles, forest fires, the king, fire, enemies, untimely death, or thieves.

original: iti śrītriratnasaundaryabhāṣāyā tripureśvarastutiḥ /
analyzed: iti śrī triratnasaundarya bhāṣāyā tripureśvara stutiḥ
translated: Thus ends the praise of the Lord of Tripura in the language of the beauty of the three jewels.

original: tarṣa vinīyā rthijano'bhyupāttasatrālayo yatra sulabdhavṛttaḥ /
analyzed: tarṣa vinīya arthi jana abhyupātta satra ālayaḥ yatra su labdha vṛttaḥ
translated: Where the king, having controlled his desires, took up residence in the sacrificial ground, and having obtained a good livelihood,

original: dadau sadāśīrvacana ca rājñe tattraipura satramiyācca sthairyam // //
analyzed: dadau ca rājñe tat traipura satram iyāt ca sthairyam
translated: Always gave blessings to the king, and that three-day sacrifice became stable.

original: vṛddhāstapobhirvayasā ca vṛddhā jñānena vṛddhā nyavasaśca hṛṣṭāḥ /
analyzed: vṛddhāḥ tapobhiḥ vayasā ca vṛddhāḥ jñānena vṛddhāḥ nyavasaḥ ca hṛṣṭāḥ
translated: The elders, who were old in austerities and age, and old in knowledge, lived there happily,

original: yatropavāsavratinaśca dhanyāstattraipura sthairyamiyācca satram // //🔽tilottamorvaśī sukeśinī ca mañjughoṣayā ghṛtācikā ca menikā sarambhayā sahāpsarāḥ /
analyzed: yatra upavāsa vratinaḥ ca dhanyāḥ tat traipura sthairyam iyāt ca satram  tilottamā urvaśī sukeśinī ca mañjughoṣayā ghṛtācikā ca menikā sarambhayā saha apsarāḥ
translated: Where the blessed ones were on a fasting vow, and that three-day sacrifice became stable.🔽Tilottama, Urvashi, Sukeshini, Manjughosha, Ghritachi, Menaka, Rambha, and other celestial nymphs,

original: divāniśa ca gīyate yaśastadīyamadbhuta naṭī bhaṭī surūpiṇī svahastadattatālikā // //
analyzed: divāniśa ca gīyate yaśaḥ tadīyam adbhuta naṭī bhaṭī surūpiṇī sva hasta datta tālikā
translated: Day and night, sing his wonderful fame. The dancer, the warrior, the beautiful one, with a clapper given by her own hand.

original: rammāstambhadidhakṣuragniriva yaḥ kṣiptaḥ pradīpo'mbhisi prāleyāśurivābhrajālapihitaḥ sūryaḥ śucau durdine /
analyzed: rammā stambha didhakṣuḥ agniḥ iva yaḥ kṣiptaḥ pradīpa umbhisi prāleya āśuḥ iva abhra jāla pihitaḥ sūryaḥ śucau durdine
translated: Like a lamp thrown into water, as if the sun were hidden by a net of clouds in a clear but bad weather,

original: gāṅgeyasya śareṇa pīḍitatanuḥ seneva yaudhiṣṭhirī buddhiḥ sundaranandajā kṣatimagād dāridryatāpolvaṇāt // //
analyzed: gāṅgeyasya śareṇa pīḍita tanuḥ senā iva yaudhiṣṭhirī buddhiḥ sundara nanda jā kṣatim agāt dāridrya tāpa ulvaṇāt  /
translated: like an army of Yudhishthira afflicted by a shaft of the son of Ganga, the mind of Sundarananda was injured by the intense heat of poverty.

original: iti śrītriratnasaundaryagāthāyā bhāṣāyā dvitīya prakṛtiratnam /
analyzed: iti śrī triratnasaundaryagāthāyāḥ bhāṣāyāḥ dvitīya prakṛti ratnam
translated: Thus ends the second chapter on the Jewel of the Story of the Three Jewels.

original: śrīgaṇeśāya namaḥ /
analyzed: śrī gaṇeśāya namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the glorious Ganesha.

original: āpāravāragotrāpatiṣu parivṛḍhaiḥ śrīmahārājarāja rājendreśapratāpairupakalitasamastarddhipauravrajeṣu /
analyzed: āpāravāra gotrā patiṣu parivṛḍhaiḥ śrī mahā rāja rāja rāja indra īśa pratāpaiḥ upakalita samasta ṛddhi paura vrajeṣu
translated: In the countries that are the foremost of the foremost of kings, the lords of the great kings, the lords of the lords of kings, who have attained all the wealth and prosperity,

original: deśeṣvārabdhapuṇyopavanavividhasaccitradevādidhāma svāste kāntīpurīya surapatinagarīlajjayaivāvatīrṇā // //
analyzed: deśeṣu ārabdha puṇya upavana vividha sat citra deva ādi dhāma svāste kāntīpurīya surapati nagarī lajjayā evā avatīrṇā
translated: the meritorious gardens and various beautiful temples of gods and others have been constructed, the city of Kanti is situated like the victorious city of the lord of gods.

original: yasyāścitrāṇi dhāmānyabhijanapaṭhitastotraramyāṇi hṛdyā nyārāmāṇi praphullairviṭapibhirabhito vāpikāpalvalaiśca /
analyzed: yasyāḥ citrāṇi dhāmāni abhijana paṭhita stotra ramyāṇi hṛdyāḥ praphullaiḥ viṭapibhiḥ abhitas vāpikā palvalaiḥ ca
translated: The beautiful and charming abodes of which are praised by the people, surrounded by gardens and blooming trees and ponds and lakes,

original: godhāmatsyodrakūrmakṣubhitajalataraṅgaiśca padmotpalāḍhyai reje kāntīpurīya kimu suranagarī svardhunī nandana vā // //
analyzed: godhā matsya udra kūrma kṣubhita jala taraṅgaiḥ ca padma utpala āḍhyaiḥ reje kāntīpurīya kimu sura nagarī svardhunī vā  /
translated: And with the waves of water agitated by fish, tortoises, and alligators, and abounding in lotuses and blue lotuses, did the city of Kānti shine forth? Or was it the celestial city, the heavenly river, or the Nandana garden?

original: yasyā rambhāsadṛkṣaiḥ sarasapaṭutarai rāgiṇīnā samakṣai rgītajñānā mṛdaṅgadhvanininadasamāhūtadivyāṅganānām /
analyzed: yasyāḥ rambhā sadṛkṣaiḥ sarasa paṭutaraiḥ rāgiṇīnā samakṣaiḥ rgīta jñānā mṛdaṅga dhvani ninada samāhūta divya aṅganānām
translated: In which, by the very sweet and charming songs of the Rāgiṇīs, resembling the Rāmba birds, of the celestial women, summoned by the sound of the Mṛdaṅga drums,

original: hāhāhūhūsutālaiḥ sataralacakita śrīyaśo gīyamāna śrutvā dvāḥstho hanūmān naṭati vijayate dvāḥsthitaḥ śrīhanūmān // //
analyzed: hāhā hūhū sutālaiḥ sa tarala cakita śrī yaśaḥ gīyamāna śrutvā dvāḥsthaḥ hanūmān naṭati vijayate dvāḥsthitaḥ śrī hanūmān  /
translated: Hearing the songs of Śrī Yaśodā, accompanied by the Hāhā and Hūhū sons, with the Tala beatings, the doorkeeper Hanumān dances. Victorious is the doorkeeper Śrī Hanumān.

original: yatrāste rājarājapratinidhidhaninā paṇyavīthibhirārā jjātasparddheva kāśyā'viralajanasamutkīrṇalīlāviśālā /🔽devyāḥ kāśīva kālyā vilasati nitarā śvetakālyāḥ pretolī ṅetākhyā kāśivāsiddhvijamithunabhiṣagbhaṭṭavāstavyamiśrāḥ // //
analyzed: yatra āste rāja rāja pratinidhi dhaninā paṇya vīthibhiḥ ārāt jāta sparddhā iva kāśyā virala jana samutkīrṇa līlā viśālā  devyāḥ kāśī iva kālyāḥ vilasati nitarā śvetakālyāḥ pretolī ṅeta ākhyā kāśi vāsit dhvija mithuna bhiṣaj bhaṭṭa vāstavya miśrāḥ
translated: Where, with the rows of shops of the king of kings, as if rivaling Kāśī, which is crowded with people and has extensive amusements,🔽The street of the ghost of the goddess Śvetā Kālikā, like the Kāśī of the goddess Kānnāpūrṇā, shines forth. The leaders are the Brāhmaṇa couple, the physician, the Bhatta, and the Vāstavyamishra, residents of Kāśī.

original: devī kāśyannapūrṇeva vilasati asantolikā yā'lakaiva paulastyasyannāpatrauṣadhivividharasaiścoṣyalehyaiśca peyaiḥ /
analyzed: devī kāśī anna pūrṇā iva vilasati asantolikā yālakā eva
translated: The goddess Kāśī, like Kānāpūrṇā, shines forth. The non-stop street, which is the very hair of Paulastya, with the various tastes of the Apatrauṣadhi herbs, and with the things to be sucked, licked, and drunk,

original: bhakṣyairbhojyaiśca /
analyzed: bhakṣyaiḥ bhojyaiḥ ca
translated: With food to eat and food to enjoy.

original: khādyairvividharasarasāgrairvaṇikśālikāsu nyastaistārāmaṭhādyairdhavalataragṛhairgopuraiḥ saudharamyaiḥ // //
analyzed: khādyaiḥ vividha rasa rasa agraiḥ vaṇij śālikāsu nyastaiḥ tārāmaṭha ādyaiḥ dhavalatara gṛhaiḥ gopuraiḥ saudha ramyaiḥ
translated: With various delicious flavors placed in the shops of merchants, with very white temples and other buildings, with beautiful mansions and watchtowers,

original: śrīkāntīnagarī sudurjayapurī saubhāgyaratnākarī trāyastriśasadṛkṣadhanyanagarī saujanyaśobhākarī /
analyzed: śrī kāntī nagarī su durjaya purī saubhāgya ratna ākarī trāyastriśa sadṛkṣa dhanya nagarī saujanya śobhā ākarī
translated: The city of Shrikanti, the very difficult to conquer city, the producer of the jewel of good fortune, the city blessed like the heaven of the thirty-three gods, the producer of the beauty of good nature,

original: nānādaivatamandirottamavatī śrībuddhisiddhīśvarī nānāratnasuvarṇakoṣanicayairvarvartti naipālikī // //
analyzed: nānā daivata mandira uttamavatī śrī buddhi siddhi īśvarī nānā ratna suvarṇa koṣa nicayaiḥ varvarti naipālikī
translated: Endowed with the best temples of various gods, the queen of the prosperous Buddhisiddhis, with treasuries of various jewels and gold, the Newari treasury,

original: nitya devasabhā tathāridalane vīrā sudharmopamā kāmye kānyasabhā suśāntasamaye śrīdharmarājī sabhā /
analyzed: deva sabhā sudharma upamā kāmye su śānta samaye śrī dharmarājī sabhā
translated: The assembly hall of the gods, the assembly hall of the enemy-destroying heroes, comparable to Sudharma, the assembly hall of the desirable Kanvas, the assembly hall of the peaceful and auspicious Dharma,

original: vīraiḥ paṇḍitatarkaśāstrakavibhirvyāpūritā sā sabhā śrīrājendramahīpatervijayate śrībhīmasenānvitā // //
analyzed: vīraiḥ paṇḍita tarka śāstra kavibhiḥ vyāpūritā sā sabhā śrī rāja indra mahīpateḥ vijayate śrī bhīmasena anvitā  /
translated: That assembly hall, filled with heroic scholars, logicians, and poets, is victorious, along with the glorious Bhimasena, in the assembly hall of the great king Indra of the rajas.

original: mahācīnasīmasthitī śāntimaitrī supātra janānandakārī guṇajñaḥ /
translated: Residing on the border of great China, the peaceful and friendly one, the giver of joy to the people, the knower of virtues,

original: vaśībhūtadākṣiṇya phairaṅgināthaḥ sa jīyāccira rājarājendrasāhaḥ // //
analyzed: vaśībhūta dākṣiṇya sa jīyāt cira rājarāja indra sāhaḥ
translated: The lord of the Franks, who has subdued and is generous, may he live long, the great king of kings, the lord of the earth.

original: mānī jñānī dhanī yaḥ parapuraharaṇe skandavaddarpadarpaḥ śrīmān rāmān sa mānnyaḥ sa hi mahimahilaścaṇḍakāṇḍaḥ paḍaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: mānī jñānī dhanī yaḥ para pura haraṇe skanda vat darpa darpaḥ śrīmān sa mān nyaḥ sa hi mahi mahilaḥ caṇḍa kāṇḍaḥ paḍaṅgaḥ
translated: The proud, the wise, the wealthy, who in robbing others' cities is as haughty as Skanda, the glorious Rama, he is to be honored, he is the mighty Candakanda, the six-limbed one.

original: jīyātpāyāddayāvānavanivaravadhūpālane labdhalakṣmā mūka loka sakampa guṇagaṇagaṇanāpārago raṅgaraktaḥ // //
analyzed: jīyāt pāyāt dayāvān avani vara vadhū pālane labdha lakṣmā mūka loka guṇa gaṇa gaṇanā pāragaḥ raṅga raktaḥ  /
translated: May he live, may he protect, the compassionate one, who has attained his goal in guarding the beloved of the best of forests, who is beyond the limit of counting the trembling virtues of the dumb people, who is red with passion.

original: bhītirnaśyati rājarājavijite gīrvāṇabhūmau yathā martyāḥ santi nirākulā na jananī tato'tyajatsatkṛpām /
analyzed: bhītiḥ naśyati rāja rāja vijite gīrvāṇa bhūmau yathā martyāḥ santi nirākulāḥ na jananī
translated: Just as on the plane of the gods conquered by Indra, fear is destroyed, so the mother did not abandon her compassion for the people who are free from anxiety.

original: sevārtha munayo'pi dūrayamunātīrāttapasyotsukāḥ nandanti tripureśvarairlasadaho kṣetra sadharmadhvaji // //
analyzed: sevā artha munayaḥ api dūra yamunā tīrāt tapasya utsukāḥ nandanti tripura īśvaraiḥ lasat aho kṣetra sa dharma dhvaji  /
translated: Even the sages, eager to practice austerities far from the banks of the Yamuna, serve for the sake of the Dharma flag that shines with the lords of Tripura in the holy place.

original: yadgopurāntakagatā vanitā babhāṣe samīlya yūthaśa apatyamukhāravindam /
analyzed: yat gopura antaka gatā vanitā babhāṣe samīlya yūthaśaḥ apatya mukha aravindam
translated: The women, having come to the end of the city gate, having closed their eyes, spoke to the lotus face of their child in a group.

original: unnāmya paśyasi gajopari rājarāja dāridryatāpaśabhane jaladāyamānam // //
analyzed: unnāmya paśyasi gaja upari rāja rāja dāridrya tāpa śabhane jaladāyamānam  /
translated: O king of kings, raising your head, you see the cloud-like one, the remover of the distress of poverty, riding on an elephant.

original: prāsādamandirajanāśrayachauunādi yadyatsudhādhavalita racita sacitram /
analyzed: prāsāda mandira janāśraya chauuna ādi yat yat sudhā dhavalita racita sa citram
translated: Whatever is supported by the people in the palace, which is white with nectar and decorated with pictures,

original: rājendrasāhanṛpateḥ sthiratāmiyāttan mallapratāpanṛpaterlikhitā śileva // //
analyzed: rāja indra sāha nṛpateḥ sthira tām iyāt tat malla pratāpa nṛpateḥ likhitā śilā iva
translated: It will be like an inscription on a stone of King Mallapraatap, the lord of kings, who was firm in his resolve.

original: rājā'ya janatāsu meghasadṛśo vaktu na śakyo mayā megho varṣati cātakasya samaye'sau sarvadā varṣati /
analyzed: rājāya janatāsu megha sadṛśaḥ vaktu na śakyaḥ mayā meghaḥ varṣati cātakasya samaye asau sarvadā varṣati
translated: I cannot describe this king among the people as being like a cloud, for the cloud rains at the time of the cataka bird, and it always rains.

original: megho varṣati cāmbha eva vipula yo hemaratnāmbara meghaḥ syāmamukhaḥ pradānasamaye yo hemagaurānanaḥ // //
analyzed: meghaḥ varṣati ca ambhaḥ eva meghaḥ syāma mukhaḥ pradāna samaye yaḥ hema gaura ānanaḥ  /
translated: The cloud rains only water, but the cloud should be golden-hued and have a golden face at the time of giving, when it has a golden face.

original: rājā dhojā bajāryā sahaja harihara devatāvargavarlāk mānī jñānī dhanī hāy parapuraharaṇe chākagū kaṇṭaka khaḥ /
analyzed: rājā dhojā bajāryā sahaja harihara mānī jñānī dhanī hāy para pura haraṇe kaṇṭaka khaḥ
translated: The king is the cloud, the queen is the lightning, Hari and Hara are the group of deities, the king is proud, wise, wealthy, and skilled in taking away the wealth of enemies, and is like a thorn to the Kankas.

original: śrīrājā rājarājendra juju juga juga āyu lāyu thva yuktī kājī sājī sajīlā madu madu madu ek he dhanī dhanya dhanye // //
analyzed: śrī rājā rājarāja indra juju juga juga āyu lāyu thva yuktī kājī sājī sajīlā madu madu madu ek he dhanī dhanya dhanye  /
translated: The glorious king, the lord of kings of kings, may you live for a hundred years, a hundred times a hundred years, with your wife, your minister, your wealth, your friends, your relatives, your servants, your elephants, your horses, your chariots, your infantry, your treasury, your granary, your army, your allies, your counselors, your brothers, your sons, your grandsons, and your great-grandsons.

original: diṣṭyā'bhivarddhatuśata śarado nṛpendro yadvacca sundaraprasāda ibhendraratnam /
analyzed: śaradaḥ nṛpa indraḥ yadvat ca sundara prasādaḥ ibha indra ratnam
translated: By good fortune, may the lord of kings prosper for a hundred autumns, just as the elephant, the jewel of the king Sundara, prospers.

original: pṛthvīnarāyaṇamahīpavinodaśālī gīrvāṇayuddhaparidhīkṛtajīvaratnam // //
translated: The king Prithvi Narayan, who delights in the wealth of the living beings who are engaged in the war of the gods, the jewel of life.

original: jyotirvidā nigamakalpita eṣa panthāḥ ṣaṣṭirdvinidhnaśaradāyuribhasya nuśca /
analyzed: jyotiḥ vidā nigama kalpitaḥ eṣa panthāḥ ṣaṣṭiḥ dvi nidhna śarad āyuḥ ibhasya nuḥ ca
translated: This is the path laid down by the astrologers, that the life of an elephant is sixty years less by two, and the life of a king is equal to that.

original: āyustadasya nṛpaterapi rājarāje ndrasyāstu bho mitha abhāṣata dṛṣṭabhūpaḥ // //
analyzed: āyuḥ tat asya nṛpateḥ api rāja rāje indrasya astu bho mitha abhāṣata dṛṣṭa bhūpaḥ  /
translated: Let the life of this king, the lord of kings, be so, said the astrologer, having seen the king.

original: nirvartyodvāhayātrāmatha sadṛśakulajyotsnike śrīmahiṣyau gurvādityādiṣūccasthitaśubhadivase lagnayadvanmuhūrte /
analyzed: nirvartya udvāha yātrām atha sadṛśa kula jyotsnike śrī mahiṣyau guru āditya ādiṣu ucca sthita śubha divase lagna yadvat muhūrte
translated: Then, having completed the marriage procession, the glorious king Saho, the ornament of the royal family, equal to eighty Vasus and the moon, on an auspicious day when the planets were in high positions, in the Lagna Yadvank Muhurta,

original: śrīmān rājendrasāho nṛpakulatikalo'śītivasvindutulye śrīpañcamyā ca jīve nigamanigaditairudvavāhe vidhānaiḥ // //
analyzed: śrīmān rāja indra sāhaḥ nṛpa kula ti kalā uśīti vasu indu tulye śrī pañcamyā ca jīve nigama nigaditaiḥ udvavāhe vidhānaiḥ  /
translated: on the glorious fifth lunar day, when Jupiter was in the sign of Jiva, he married the two queens, born in noble families, with the prescribed rituals mentioned in the scriptures.

original: ḍhakkādyāṇakavādyavādanaparāstauryatrikā gāyakā veṇudhmāḥ karatālikāḥ suvacaso gāndharvikā nāṭakāḥ /
analyzed: ḍhakka ādyāṇaka vādya vādana parāḥ tauryatrikāḥ gāyakāḥ veṇudhmāḥ karatālikāḥ suvacasaḥ gāndharvikāḥ nāṭakāḥ
translated: The musicians, playing the Dhakkas, Ayakas, and other instruments, the singers, the flute-players, the clappers, the eloquent Gandharvas, the actors,

original: tāṭaṅkāgadahārakaṅkaṇalasaccīnāśukottasakai rlabdhairdikṣu vitenire nṛpapatermūrtta yaśastatkṣaṇe // //
analyzed: tāṭaṅkā gada hāra kaṅkaṇa lasat cīnā śuka uttasakaiḥ labdhaiḥ dikṣu vitenire nṛpa pateḥ mūrtta yaśaḥ tad kṣaṇe  /
translated: with the ornaments of earrings, necklaces, bracelets, and the Chinese silk upper garments obtained from all directions, spread the king's fame in all directions in an instant.

original: diṣṭyā tvayā sa bhagavān nṛpatirmayāpi dṛṣṭaḥ pureva nṛpapṛthvinarāyaṇo'yam /
analyzed: diṣṭyā tvayā sa bhagavān nṛpatiḥ mayā api dṛṣṭaḥ purā iva
translated: By good fortune, you have seen that blessed king, just as I have seen this king Narayana of the earth before.

original: ittha mithaḥ prabhaṇita muditairaśīti varṣottaraiḥ sapalitaiḥ skhaladakṣaraughaiḥ // //
