analyzed: ittha mithas varṣa uttaraiḥ sa palitaiḥ skhalat akṣara oghaiḥ  /
translated: Thus did they converse with each other, delighted, with their hair turning grey, their voices faltering.

original: sihapratāpanṛpatirbhagavān mayāpi dṛṣṭo'valambitakarāṅgulinā janetuḥ /
analyzed: sihapratāpa nṛpatiḥ bhagavān mayā api dṛṣṭaḥ uvalambita kara aṅgulinā janetuḥ
translated: I too have seen King Sihaprabha, with my father's hand on my shoulder.

original: varṇena puṣkaratayā vapuṣā ca tulyo diṣṭyādya tatsutasutātmaja eṣa rājā // //
analyzed: varṇena puṣkara tayā vapuṣā ca tulyaḥ diṣṭyā adya tad suta suta ātmajaḥ eṣa rājā
translated: By his complexion, lotus-like eyes, and form, he is the equal of the king. By good fortune, today his son's son is the king.

original: naivā'paśya hi gīrvāṇayudhanṛpamaha śītalāyāḥ pratīpā dābāla tāmrakośīgahanamupagato bhrātṛvargeṇa sākam /
analyzed: na eva apaśya hi gīrvāṇa yudha nṛpa maha śītalāyāḥ pratīpā dābāla tāmrakośī gahanam upagataḥ bhrātṛ vargeṇa sākam
translated: I did not see the king of the gods, the enemy of Shiva, in the cool waters of the Ganges, but went with my brothers to the dense forest of the Tamrakoti mountains.

original: śrutvā yatkīrtimārādahaha dhṛtiharo nindamāno'smi bhāgya diṣṭyā paśyāmi tatsūnumamumavanipa rājarājendrasāham // //
analyzed: śrutvā yad kīrti mārāt ahaha dhṛti haraḥ nindamānaḥ asmi bhāgya diṣṭyā paśyāmi tad sūnum amum avanipa rāja rāja indra sāham  /
translated: Hearing the fame of Shiva, alas! I am censured as one who destroys fortitude. By good fortune, I see his son, this king, the lord of kings of kings.

original: dhanyā'raṇyānyagamyā ṭhigaṇasamabhidhā vekravallīvitānā yatrāsan śītalātīḥ śataśa atitarā śītalālhāditāyām /
analyzed: dhanya araṇyānya gamyāḥ ṭhigaṇa samabhidhāḥ vekra vallī vitānāḥ yatra āsan śataśas śītala ālhāditāyām
translated: Blessed are the cool waters of the Ganges, in the forest inaccessible to crowds, covered with a canopy of creepers, where there were hundreds of cool waters, extremely cool and delightful.

original: pratyāvṛtyāhamasyāḥ sa ca sa ca sasakhaḥ svasti gīrvāṇayuddha diṣṭyā paśyāmi dīnānanu janitakṛpa dravyavṛṣṭyāramantam // //
analyzed: pratyāvṛtya aham asyāḥ sa ca sa ca sa sakhaḥ svasti gīrvāṇa yuddha diṣṭyā paśyāmi dīna ananu janita kṛpa dravya vṛṣṭyā āramantam  /
translated: Having returned from there, with my friend, I am well. By good fortune, I see him raining wealth on the poor, generating compassion.

original: svastiśrīmaṇicūḍaparvataguhāmāśritya kṛcchrādaha jīvan bhagnajanitṛmātṛsahajairunmuktajīvātukaḥ /
analyzed: svasti śrī maṇicūḍa parvata guhām āśritya kṛcchrāt aha jīvan bhagna janitṛ mātṛ sahajaiḥ unmukta jīvātukaḥ
translated: Having somehow survived, my life spared by my father, mother, and siblings, I now reside in the cave of the mountain of the crown jewel of good fortune, my body covered in wounds.

original: yoginyā aniśa ca sevanavaśāt tatpūjakenaiva ya nnaivedya mama dīyate pratidina tenaiva jīvāmyaham // //
analyzed: yoginyāḥ aniśa ca sevana vaśāt tad pūjakena eva yat naivedya mama dīyate pratidina tena eva jīvāmi aham
translated: By the grace of the yoginī, I am sustained by the offerings of food given to me daily by the worshipper of the deity, who serves her constantly.

original: śrīsavadyugahastihastividhuge āṣāḍhaśukle budhe śrīgaurīsutithau nṛpaḥ paśupateḥ sandarśanātha gataḥ /
analyzed: śrī savat yuga hasti hasti vidhuge āṣāḍha śukle budhe śrī gaurī su tithau nṛpaḥ paśupateḥ sandarśana atha gataḥ
translated: On the third lunar day of the bright fortnight of Āṣāḍha, when the moon was in the constellation of Puṣya, the king went to visit Lord Śiva.

original: dṛṣṭo me vasuvṛṣṭibhirbudhajanaiḥ prastūyamānaḥ śanai rnāga hāṭakasabhava maṇigaṇaiścitra śivāyārpayat // //🔽sākṣānnārāyaṇāśaḥ paśupaticaraṇoddhūtadhūlīvitānaḥ śrīmān rājendrasāhaḥ sapadi viruruce labdhabhargaikyabhāvaḥ /
analyzed: dṛṣṭaḥ me vasu vṛṣṭibhiḥ budha janaiḥ prastūyamānaḥ śanais rnāga hāṭaka sabhava maṇi gaṇaiḥ citra śivāya arpayat  / sākṣāt nārāyaṇa āśaḥ paśupati caraṇa uddhūta dhūlī vitānaḥ śrīmān rāja indra sāhaḥ sapadi viruruce labdha bharga aikya bhāvaḥ
translated: He saw the Lord, slowly worshipped by the people with showers of wealth, and offered various gems and jewels to the assembly hall named Nāga Hāṭaka, for the sake of auspiciousness.🔽The glorious king, who was devoted to Lord Nārāyaṇa, whose canopy was the dust raised by the feet of Lord Paśupati, and who had attained oneness with Lord Bhairava, shone forth immediately.

original: nāste nārāyaṇacca parama atita / / prītipātra paśūnā patyuḥ sabhūya tau dvau paśupatinṛpatī rakṣato bhūrbhuvaḥsvaḥ // //
analyzed: tau dvau paśupati nṛpatī rakṣataḥ bhūḥ bhuvaḥ svar
translated: There is no one greater than Nārāyaṇa, the supreme recipient of devotion. The two, Paśupati and the king, protect the three worlds - earth, atmosphere, and heaven.

original: jyeṣṭhe māsyasite dale haritithau savat ṣaḍaṣṭāṣṭabhū yāte kāvyadine mudā vijayate bhaktāabhidha pattanam /
analyzed: jyeṣṭhe māsi asite dale hari tithau yāte kāvya dine mudā vijayate pattanam
translated: In the month of Jyaishtha, on the dark lunar day, when the sun was in the 6th, 8th or 12th house, on a Tuesday, the city of the devotees of Lord Hari was filled with joy.

original: śrīrājendramahīpatiḥ purabhavaiḥ svastyāśiṣā nanditaḥ saubhikṣa janatā jagāda nṛpateḥ prodyatpratāpārciṣā // //
analyzed: śrī rāja indra mahīpatiḥ pura bhavaiḥ svasti āśiṣā nanditaḥ saubhikṣa jana tāḥ jagāda nṛpateḥ prodyat pratāpa arciṣā  /
translated: King Rajendra, the lord of the earth, was delighted by the blessings of the people of his city. The prosperous people spoke to the king, whose glory was rising like a flame.

original: sthānādgaṇeśiturupākramato nṛpasyā ṣāḍhe kuhūyuji kuje'nhi babhūva śobhā /
analyzed: sthānāt gaṇeśituḥ upākramataḥ nṛpasya ā ṣāḍhe kuhū yuji babhūva śobhā
translated: From the abode of Ganesha, the king's splendor arose in the month of Shravana, on the day of Kuhu, when Mars was in the 6th house.

original: no vṛṣṭamātapitamidradivākarābhyā pratyagramarddhaśaśiśekharalokadṛṣṭyā // //
analyzed: no vṛṣṭam ātapita midra divākarābhyā pratyagram arddha śaśiśekhara loka dṛṣṭyā
translated: It was seen by the people as if by the rising half-moon, not scorched by the sun and rain.

original: lokairitastata iti dravita nu panthāḥ ko vā bhaviṣyati mahīpasamāgamāya /
analyzed: lokaiḥ itas tatas iti dravita nu panthāḥ kaḥ vā bhaviṣyati mahīpa samāgamāya
translated: The path was melted by the people here and there. Who will come for the king's arrival?

original: nirgacchate punaramātyavareṇa sāka mutkaṇṭhayeti pratigopuramīkṣate sma // //
analyzed: nirgacchate punar amātya vareṇa sāka m utkaṇṭhayā iti prati gopuram īkṣate sma
translated: Again, with the best of ministers, he looked out from the main gate, longing to go out.

original: prācyāmairāvatākhya diśi vidiśi babandhurdigīśāḥ karīndrā nāgneyyā puṇḍarīka kramaśa iti gaja vāmana kaumuda ca /
analyzed: prācyām airāvata ākhya diśi vidiśi babandhuḥ digīśāḥ kari indrāḥ nāgneyyā puṇḍarīka kramaśas iti
translated: In the eastern direction called Airavata, the lords of the directions bound their elephant kings, in the southeast, Pundarika, and so on, the elephants Vamana and Kaumuda.

original: svastiśrīrājarājendradharaṇipatibhi svastyamarsihathāpā patyaśribhīmadikpaiḥsahayatamatayo /
analyzed: svasti śrī rāja rāja indra dharaṇi patibhiḥ svasti amarsi hathāpā
translated: May the kings, lords of the earth, be victorious, along with the powerful and greatly wise ones, the lords of the directions like Indra.

original: hyekato yogapadyāt // //
analyzed: hi ekatas yogapadyāt
translated: On one side, due to the simultaneity of yoga,

original: duḥśālā hastiśālā śithilagajaghaṭā jīryamāṇā viditvā nūtnā prācyāmavācyāmatha vidiśi manohāriṇī stambhanaddhām /
analyzed: duḥśālā hasti śālā śithila gaja ghaṭā jīryamāṇā viditvā nūtnā prācyām avācyām atha vidiśi manohāriṇī stambha naddhām
translated: having known the old elephant stable, with loose groups of elephants, decaying, in the east, in the west, or in the intermediate directions, charming to the mind, with pillars tied,

original: kṛtvā lakṣmīprasāda gajahavaḍaprasāda ca devīprasāda krudhyanmotiprasāda tadupari ca jaharveṣasajña babandha // //
analyzed: kṛtvā lakṣmī prasāda gajahavaḍa prasāda ca devī prasāda tad upari ca babandha  /
translated: having done the favor of Lakshmi, the favor of the elephant, the favor of the goddess, the favor of the angry one, and on top of that, the one known as Jaharvesha, he bound.

original: nāgā'sāvamaraprasāda iti yaḥ saundaryavīryodayai rdevendrebhasamaḥ suśikṣitaguṇaḥ saubhāgyaratnākaraḥ /
analyzed: nāga asau amara prasādaḥ iti yaḥ saundarya vīrya udayaiḥ deva indra ibha samaḥ su śikṣita guṇaḥ saubhāgya ratna ākaraḥ
translated: That elephant, the favor of the immortals, with the rise of beauty and valor, equal to Indra, well-trained in qualities, an ocean of the jewel of good fortune,

original: yaddantopari viṣṭarāsanavare sthitvā japādikriyā kartuḥ satpuruṣārthado vijayate bhūpālacūḍāmaṇeḥ // //
analyzed: yad danta upari viṣṭarāsana vare sthitvā japa ādi kriyā kartuḥ sat puruṣa artha daḥ vijayate bhūpāla cūḍāmaṇeḥ  /
translated: standing on the top of whose tusk, in an excellent seat, performing the rites of japa and so on, bestowing the good human goal, the crest-jewel of kings, is victorious.

original: mattebhendraikadantaḥ sa jayati nṛpatervīralakṣmīprasādo hṛṣṭāṅgo lakṣaṇaudhairnigamanigaditairhastiratna garīyān /
analyzed: matta ibha indra ekadantaḥ sa jayati nṛpateḥ vīra lakṣmī prasādaḥ hṛṣṭa aṅgaḥ lakṣaṇa odhaiḥ nigama nigaditaiḥ hastiratna garīyān
translated: The single tusk of the lord of maddened elephants, the favor of the king's glorious beauty, with a delighted body, the most precious elephant described by the characteristics,

original: dānādhyakṣastiraścā svakaravigalitaiḥ svānnapiṇḍekṣadaṇḍaiḥ poṣṭā kreṅkāravaktā suraṇitanigaḍo varṣmaṇā vindhyaśailaḥ // //
analyzed: dāna adhyakṣaḥ sva kara vigalitaiḥ sva anna piṇḍa ikṣa daṇḍaiḥ poṣṭā kreṅkāra vaktā su raṇita nigaḍaḥ varṣmaṇā vindhya śailaḥ  /
translated: The lord of giving, the protector, with the sticks of his own food falling from his hand, the Vindhya mountain, with its fetters jingling, speaks with a creaking sound.

original: martyānā durgrahebhyo vitarati hi vimukti haṭhādvakratuṇḍo yadbhaktyā siddhimāpustridaśamunivarā vāmadevādayaśca /
analyzed: durgrahebhyaḥ vitarati hi vimukti haṭhāt vakratuṇḍaḥ yad bhaktyā siddhim āpuḥ tridaśa muni varāḥ vāmadeva ādayaḥ ca
translated: The one with the curved tusks forcibly grants liberation to mortals from evil planets, by whose devotion the best of gods and sages, Vamadeva and others, attained perfection.

original: pārvatyā gaṅgayā vā gaṇayata aniśa ṣaḍguṇa cāgryagaṇya ta vande caikadanta gaṇapatimabhaya kāryasiddhernidānam // //🔽vīro lakṣmīprasādo madayati ca muhuḥ stambhamālambate'ho vakti kre kre kimārājjanaralasaciva vīkṣya rājendrarājam /
analyzed: pārvatyā gaṅgayā vā gaṇayata aniśa ṣaḍguṇa ca agrya gaṇya ta vande ca ekadanta gaṇapatim abhaya kārya siddheḥ nidānam  / vīraḥ lakṣmī prasādaḥ madayati ca muhur stambham ālambatā iho vakti kre kre kim ārāt jana rala saciva vīkṣya rāja indra rājam
translated: Counting the six qualities of Parvati, Ganga, and the foremost of the group, I constantly bow to the one with the single tusk, the cause of fearlessness and accomplishment, the lord of the Ganas.🔽The hero, favored by Lakshmi, is intoxicated and repeatedly leans on a pillar. Alas! He speaks kre kre. Seeing the king of kings, the chief minister of the people,

original: stambha prakramya śabdāyitanijanigaḍaḥ karṇatāla dadāno rājanmā jetumāyātviti gaganatalādabhrahastīti buddhyā // //
analyzed: stambha prakramya śabdāyita nija nigaḍaḥ karṇa tāla dadānaḥ rājan mā jetum āyātu iti gagana talāt abhra hastī iti buddhyā
translated: The one with fetters jingling, giving a clap with his ear, thinking O king, may you not be victorious, the cloud-elephant comes from the sky.

original: bhūyo bhūyaśca sasnau ghaṭagalitajale śīkara gaṇḍuṣottha projjhan prānteṣu bhukta dharaṇipatikarāt kattṛṇa kuñcarāśam /
analyzed: bhūyas bhūyas ca sasnau ghaṭa galita jale śīkara gaṇḍuṣa uttha projjhan prānteṣu bhukta dharaṇi pati karāt kattṛṇa kuñca rāśam
translated: Again and again he bathed in the water dripping from the pot, avoiding the spray and mouthfuls, at the edges, eating the grass from the trunk of the elephant given by the king of the earth.

original: bhuṅkte cāyācitānna tryuṣaṇamadhughṛta śālinīvāraśaṣpa rājendra vāhayāno hatimiva munirāḍ vīralakṣmīprasādaḥ // //
analyzed: bhuṅkte ca a yācita anna tryuṣaṇa madhu ghṛta śāli nīvāra śaṣpa rāja indra vāhayānaḥ hatim iva muni rāj vīra lakṣmī prasādaḥ  /
translated: And he ate unasked food, with the three pungent spices, honey, ghee, rice, and barley grass, O king of kings, riding on the elephant, like the sage Vīralakṣmīprasāda.

original: mallendro yo durghaṭānā karīṇā svasti śrīmān maṅkuṇaḥ śrīprasādaḥ /
analyzed: malla indraḥ yaḥ svasti śrīmān maṅkuṇaḥ śrī prasādaḥ
translated: The lord of wrestlers, who is difficult to subdue, is auspicious, the prosperous Maṅkuṇa, the grace of prosperity.

original: rāhuryadvannigrahe / / candrasūryau tadvaddhastīn durvinītān pinaṣṭi // //
analyzed: rāhuḥ yadvat nigrahe candra sūryau tadvat hastīn durvinītān pinaṣṭi
translated: Just as Rāhu is in the eclipse of the moon and sun, so he crushes the unruly elephants.

original: svastiśrīmadrājarājendrarājño hastī jīyānmaṅkuṇaḥ śrīprasādaḥ /
analyzed: svasti śrīmat rāja rāja indra rājñaḥ hastī śrī prasādaḥ
translated: Long live the elephant Maṅkuṇa, the grace of prosperity, of the king of kings, the king of kings.

original: yenaikenā'nekaśo vanyanāgāḥ sāhāyyenānīyate rājaveśma // //🔽śrīrājendramahīpatirvijayate śrīmaṅkuṇāṅgasthitaḥ sākṣāt pṛthvinarāyaṇaḥ prathamataḥ śrīsundarebhasthitaḥ /
analyzed: yena ekena anekaśas vanya nāgāḥ sāhāyyena ānīyate rāja veśma 🔽śrī rāja indra mahīpatiḥ vijayate śrī maṅkuṇa aṅga sthitaḥ sākṣāt pṛthvinarāyaṇaḥ prathamatas śrī sundara ibha sthitaḥ
translated: By whom many wild elephants are brought to the king's palace with the help of one.

original: thāpā ambarasihasūnumaṇinā śrībhīmasenena ya śchatragrāhisukhena kāntinagare dinānukampo vibhuḥ // //
analyzed: ambarasiha sūnu maṇinā śrī bhīmasenena yaḥ chatra grāhi sukhena kāntinagare dina anukampaḥ vibhuḥ
translated: The Lord was compassionately served for many days in the city of Kanti by the illustrious Bhimasena, the son of Thapa Ambarasiha, who was skilled in holding the umbrella.

original: niraṅkuśavisarpiṇā paramahasavacchyāmala gajena pariśikṣitaśamadamanidhidhyāsana
analyzed: niraṅkuśa visarpiṇā parama hasa vat śyāmala gajena pariśikṣita śama dama nidhi dhyāsana
translated: The king, who was like a dark elephant roaming without restraint, who was a treasure of tranquility and self-control, who was skilled in meditation,

original: samīraṇanirodhana narepatīndrasevā kṛtā mṛdāharaṇaśīlitaḥ paramahasanāgo'tyagāt //
analyzed: samīraṇa nirodhana narepati indra sevā kṛtā mṛdā āharaṇa śīlitaḥ
translated: who had restrained his breath, who had served the lord of kings, who was accustomed to gathering dust, the great elephant of laughter, surpassed all.

original: pṛthvīnārāyaṇena prathamamatiruṣā proṣitā kīrtinārī sāpatnyātsātiruṣṭā'dhidiśamanugatā pāśulevotpathasthā /
analyzed: pṛthvīnārāyaṇena prathamam ati ruṣā proṣitā kīrtinārī sāpatnyāt sā ati ruṣṭā adhidiśam anugatā pāśulā iva utpatha sthā
translated: The woman of fame, first banished by the angry Narayana of the earth, that angry woman, following the lord of the directions, like a she-goat standing on a wrong path,

original: sāraṇyānī praviṣṭā davadahanamadhāvacchucā sā ca vātai rnītā dhūmairdvipānā kulamabhavadaraṇyānija dhūmravarṇam //
analyzed: sā araṇyānī praviṣṭā dava dahanam adhāvat śucā sā ca vātaiḥ rnītā dhūmaiḥ dvipānā kulam abhavat araṇyānija dhūmra varṇam
translated: entered the forest, and she, scorched by the forest fire, was carried by the winds, and by the smoke, the herd of elephants became smoky-colored in the forest.

original: adyaitaddhastivṛnde dhavalimagajarāḍeka uccairvapuṣmān śrīmadrājendrarāja sacivakulamaṇi bhīmasena niṣevya /
analyzed: adya etat hasti vṛnde dhavalima gaja rāj ekaḥ uccais vapuṣmān śrīmat rāja indra rāja saciva kula maṇi bhīmasena niṣevya
translated: Today, in this herd of elephants, the lord of elephants, the most exalted in form, the crest-jewel of the ministers of the illustrious king of kings, Bhimasena, having served,

original: varṇa sva dhūmalipta kṣapayitumiva sa tryūṣaṇājātikoṣā jyājājībhṛṣṭamattu śaraṇadamagamanmātharavsihasārthaḥ //
analyzed: dhūma lipta kṣapayitum iva sa
translated: As if to dispel the smoke-stained complexion, the caravan of merchants, roasted with three-pepper spices, went to the shelter of a forest of jujube trees fried with cumin seeds.

original: no manye dṛḍhabandhanakṣatamida naivāṅkuśodghāṭana skandhārohaṇatāḍanātparibhava naivānyadeśāgamam /
analyzed: na u manye dṛḍha bandhana kṣatam idam na eva aṅkuśa udghāṭana skandha ārohaṇa tāḍanāt paribhava na eva anya deśa āgamam
translated: I do not think this is the injury of a firm bond, nor the opening of a goad, nor the humiliation of mounting another's shoulders and being beaten, nor coming to another country.

original: cintā me janayanti cetasi yathā smṛtvā svayūtha vane sihatrāsitabhīrubhīrukarabhā yāsyanti kasyāśrayam //
analyzed: cintā me janayanti cetasi yathā smṛtvā sva yūtha vane siha trāsita bhīru bhīru karabhāḥ yāsyanti kasya āśrayam
translated: But the thought of how the timid and frightened young elephants, remembering their own herd in the forest, terrified by the lion, will go to whose shelter, causes anxiety in my mind.

original: yadetadativistṛta bhavatu rājarājendra bho jalasthalavanāntare viharataḥ sabhīmasya te /
analyzed: yat etat ati vistṛta bhavatu rāja rāja indra bho jala sthala vana antare viharataḥ sa bhīmasya te
translated: O King of kings, let this be very extensive, for you who wander with Bhimasena in the water, on land, and in the forests.

original: vinaiva karaṇa kareṇuriha rūpamāsādhyate manīṣigaṇasammata varadarājasūtre hitam //
analyzed: vinā eva karaṇa kareṇuḥ iha rūpam āsādhyate manīṣi gaṇa sammata varadarājasūtre hitam
translated: Without any means, the elephant is made to assume a form here, beneficial in the Varada Raja Sutra, approved by the assembly of wise ones.

original: karṇau naiṣa dadhāti naiṣa viṣayo vāhasya dohasya vā tṛptirnāsya mahodarasya bahubhirvaśaiḥ palālairapi /
analyzed: karṇau nā eṣa dadhāti nā eṣa viṣayaḥ vāhasya dohasya vā tṛptiḥ nā asya mahodarasya bahubhiḥ vaśaiḥ palālaiḥ api
translated: He does not put on earrings, nor is he the object of a horse or a milch cow, nor is he satisfied by many loads of straw.

original: ataḥ paramaśvaratna likhyate /
analyzed: atas param aśvaratna likhyate
translated: After this, the supreme elephant jewel is described.

original: sauvaśve dharaṇīpatau kimu śacībhartā spṛhā nācare dājāneyaśatākule pavanavegoccaiḥśravāḥ kevalaḥ /
analyzed: sauvaśve dharaṇī patau kimu śacī bhartā spṛhā na acare dājāneya śata ākule pavana vega uccaiḥśravāḥ kevalaḥ
translated: When the lord of the earth is a good horse, does Indra, the lord of Shachi, feel any desire? Only the horse Ucchaihshrava, with the speed of the wind, in the family of a hundred sons of Arjuna.

original: vānāyūdbhavapārasīkajahayaiḥ kāmbojibhirvāhlikai hreṣāskanditavalgitairanudina merurbanībhramyate // //
analyzed: kāmbojibhiḥ vāhlikaiḥ hreṣā skandita valgitaiḥ anudina meruḥ banī bhramyate  /
translated: The Meru mountain is made to tremble daily by the neighing, leaping and prancing of the horses born in Vanayu, Persia, Jahnu, Kamboja and Vahlika.

original: utplutyotplutya vegād dharaṇipatipratāpānalajvālayeva pluṣṭā nepāladhātrīmiti manasi bhavadvāhanā manyamānāḥ /
analyzed: utplutya utplutya vegāt dharaṇipati pratāpa anala jvālayā iva pluṣṭāḥ nepāla dhātrīm iti manasi bhavat vāhanāḥ manyamānāḥ
translated: Thinking that your horse, leaping again and again as if burning the Nepalese fig tree with the flames of the fire of the king's valor, is in its mind,

original: smṛtvā kṣīrābdhiśainya tripuraśivamahāsnānatoyaughamiśra vāgmatyambhaḥ pavitra plavitumiva haṭhāttuṇḍikhelād dravanti // //
analyzed: smṛtvā kṣīrābdhi śainya tripura śiva mahā snāna toya ogha miśra vāgmatī ambhaḥ pavitra plavitum iva haṭhāt tuṇḍi khelāt dravanti  /
translated: Remembering the water of the Ganges mixed with the water of the great bath of Shiva after the destruction of Tripura, the swans seem to rush with the play of their beaks as if to swim in the sacred water of the Ganges.

original: hā kaṣṭa kathamasya pṛṣṭhaśikhare golī samāropyate ko gṛhṇāti kaparddakairalamiti grāmyairgajo hāsyate //
analyzed: hā kaṣṭa katham asya pṛṣṭha śikhare golī samāropyate kaḥ gṛhṇāti kaparddakaiḥ alam iti grāmyaiḥ gajaḥ hāsyate
translated: Alas! How is a ball placed on the top of its back? Who will take it with matted locks? The elephant is laughed at by the villagers.

original: ūrddhva cādhaśca nīta turagaparivṛḍhenā'munā vaktravimba kisvijjetu maghono'śvamiva gaganaga tarkita vimbadṛṣṭyā /
analyzed: ūrddhva ca adhas ca nīta turaga parivṛḍhena amunā vaktra vimba kisvid jetu maghonā ūśvam iva gagana ga tarkita vimba dṛṣṭyā
translated: By the best of horses, this face-disc, taken up and down, is seen with a gaze like the disc of the sun in the sky, as if to conquer Indra's horse.

original: protha visphārya coccaiḥ sutaralacakita hreṣita hrāsabuddhyā rājannoḍḍīya yātyeṣa ha ha yadi niyantā sudhīrbhīmasenaḥ // //
analyzed: protha visphārya ca uccais su tarala cakita hreṣita hrāsa buddhyā rājan ā uḍḍīya yāti eṣa ha ha yadi niyantā sudhīḥ bhīmasenaḥ  /
translated: O king, if the intelligent Bhimasena, the controller, flies up with the thought of diminishing the loud neighing and the frightened whinnying of the horse that is neighing loudly after stretching its neck, then he goes away.

original: rallairmallanṛpaiḥ puraikasamaye gandharvayātrā kṛtā saivādya prativāsara ca lumuḍīśrībhadrakālīmude /
analyzed: rallaiḥ malla nṛpaiḥ pura eka samaye gandharva yātrā kṛtā sā eva adya prativāsara ca lumuḍī śrī bhadrakālī mude
translated: At one time, the Gandharva festival was performed by the Malla kings of Ralla, and today it is performed every day at the rising of the glorious Bhadrakali.

original: tattanmallanṛpaśriyā hi śataśo drāg jitvarairbhūṣṇubhiḥ śrīrājendradharādhipairjanaralaśrībhīmasenāñcitaiḥ // //
analyzed: tad tad malla nṛpa śriyā hi śataśas drāk jitvaraiḥ bhūṣṇubhiḥ śrī rāja indra dharādhipaiḥ jana rala śrī bhīmasena añcitaiḥ
translated: Having quickly conquered hundreds of times with the glory of those Malla kings, with the glorious kings, lords of the earth, adorned with the glory of the people and Bhimasena,

original: mañjūṣāyā prasūtidvayamatha suṣuve'raṇyavadvyāghrapatnī pusaḥ patnīva hṛṣyatparijananicitā ruddhavātāyanā ca /🔽māsairbhakṣyaiśca peyairbalavadapaghanā santatī rakṣyamāṇā dhanyā sā kāṣṭhamaṇḍe vipaṇipariṇatā bhūmipaprītipātram // //
analyzed: mañjūṣāyāḥ prasūti dvayam atha suṣuve iraṇya vat vyāghra patnī pusaḥ patnī iva hṛṣyat parijana nicitā ruddha vātāyanā ca  māsaiḥ bhakṣyaiḥ ca peyaiḥ balavat apaghanā santatiḥ rakṣyamāṇā dhanyā sā kāṣṭha maṇḍe vipaṇi pariṇatā bhūmipa prītipātram  /
translated: Then the tigress gave birth to two in the basket, like in the forest, and the wife of Pusha, with the windows closed, was filled with the delighted servants.🔽Protected by the series of food, drink, and strength, the blessed one, turned into a commodity in the wooden house, became a recipient of the king's favor.

original: dhanyo rājendrasāho yadatulamahasaḥ sāttvikād vairabhāva muktvānyonya tiraśco hayakapikariṇo gaṇḍakāḥ sairibhāśca /
analyzed: dhanyaḥ rāja indra sāhaḥ yat atula mahasaḥ sāttvikāt vaira bhāva muktvā anyonya tiraścaḥ haya kapi kariṇaḥ gaṇḍakāḥ sairibhāḥ ca
translated: Blessed is the king's lord Saho, who, having abandoned the enmity born of the Sattvika emotion of incomparable joy, the animals, the horse, monkey, and camel, the elephants, and the buffaloes,

original: sārddha vyāghreṇa yuddhāya haha visṛjatā sāmyatāmeva jagmuḥ sāmukhyībhūya bhīme sthitavati janatā vairabhāva kva kuryāt // //🔽śrāvaṇyā pūrṇimāyā śravaṇabhṛgudine sihage saptasaptau śrīmatkumbheśatīrthe lalitapuri mahārājarājendrasāhaḥ /
analyzed: sārddha vyāghreṇa yuddhāya haha visṛjatā sāmya tām eva jagmuḥ sāmukhyībhūya bhīme sthitavati janatā vaira bhāva kva kuryāt  / śrāvaṇyā pūrṇimāyā śravaṇa bhṛgu dine siha ge saptasaptau śrīmat kumbheśatīrthe lalita puri mahā rāja rāja indra sāhaḥ
translated: When Bhima stood before them, having come face to face with the tiger to fight with it, the people, having given up their enmity, went to equality with him.🔽On the full moon day of Shravana, in the month of Shravana, on a Saturday, in the year of the lion, the king of kings, Maharaja Raja,🔽bathed in the auspicious Kumbhesh Tīrtha in Lalitapura, for the destruction of the suffering of poverty. Skilled in battle, he rained wealth,

original: sasnau dāridryatāpāya sa raṇakuśalo dravyavarṣeṇa harṣā dāśīrbhirnandyamāno muditapurajanairdīrghakāla sa jīyāt // //
analyzed: sasnau dāridrya tāpāya sa raṇa kuśalaḥ dravya varṣeṇa harṣā dāśīrbhiḥ nandyamānaḥ mudita pura janaiḥ dīrgha kāla sa jīyāt  /
translated: and was delighted by the maidservants, and lived for a long time, being praised by the joyful citizens.

original: śrāvaṇyā hastaṣaṣṭhyā sitadalagabudhe ṣaḍgajāṣṭādaśābde snāti śrīmatyagādhe maṇisarasi sama mātṛbhī rājarājaḥ /🔽rājarddhyā pūjito'smin vitarati maṇiliṅgeśvarastatsadṛkṣā patyaddhirājarājāya nṛpaparibṛḍhāya kṣaradvīcihastaiḥ // //
analyzed: śrāvaṇyā hasta ṣaṣṭhyā sita dala ga budhe ṣaṣ gaja aṣṭādaśa abde snāti śrīmati agādhe maṇi sarasi mātṛbhiḥ rājarājaḥ  rāja ṛddhyā pūjitaḥ asmin vitarati maṇi liṅga īśvaraḥ tad sadṛkṣā pati addhi rāja rājāya nṛpa paribṛḍhāya kṣara dvīci hastaiḥ  /
translated: On the sixth of the bright fortnight of Shravana, when the moon was in Hasta, in the year of the lion, the king of kings bathed in the deep and auspicious lake of jewels, along with his mothers.🔽Honored with royal prosperity in this world, the Lord of the Jewel Linga bestows upon the king of kings, the chief of men, the wealth of a universal monarch, with waves of nectar in his hands.

original: pratāpādhikyenodadhiśamanamāśaṅkya vasati sthalākāṅkṣī rājendranṛpamaviśat pītavasanaḥ /
analyzed: pratāpa ādhikyena udadhi śamanam āśaṅkya vasati sthala ākāṅkṣī rāja indra nṛpam aviśat pīta vasanaḥ
translated: Fearing the pacification of the ocean due to his excessive valor, the king, desiring dry land, entered the king of kings, dressed in yellow robes.

original: ramā koṣa vāṇīmamṛtamahirājo'simanalaḥ pratāpa vāhatva turagapatirindustu mukuṭam // //🔽rājendrasya surendravikramasujanmāhaḥ sulagna yadā savat ṣaḍvasuhastibhūmirabhavaddurgotsavī saptamī /
analyzed: pratāpa turagapatiḥ induḥ tu mukuṭam  / rāja indrasya sura indra vikrama su janma ahar su lagna yadā ṣaṣ vasu hasti bhūmiḥ abhavat durga utsavī saptamī
translated: Lakshmi is his treasury, the nectar-filled ocean is his king, the sword is his fire, the lord of horses is his vehicle, and the moon is his crown.🔽When the king, whose birth was auspicious due to his valor like that of Indra, was ruling the earth with six excellent horses and seven villages, on the seventh day of the festival of Durga.

original: dāridryārṇavaśoṣaka trijagatā śrīpṛthvinārāyaṇaḥ sāṅgaiḥ ṣaḍbhirivānvayairavatatārāsmin mahīmaṇḍale // //🔽yadvattatsamaye suśāliyavagodhūmādisasyarddhayaḥ kagūmāṣasatīnasarṣapatilekṣūṇā mahāsampadaḥ /🔽meghāḥ kālasuvarṣiṇaśca taravo gucchaiḥ prasūnaiḥ phalai rāḍhyā bhūrirasapradāśca paśavaḥ santyatra janmotsave // //
analyzed: dāridrya arṇava śoṣaka trijagatā śrī pṛthvi nārāyaṇaḥ sa aṅgaiḥ ṣaḍbhiḥ iva anvayaiḥ avatatāra asmin mahī maṇḍale  / yadvat tad samaye su śāli yava godhūma ādi sasya ṛddhayaḥ kagū māṣa satīna sarṣapa tila ikṣūṇām mahā sampadaḥ  meghāḥ kāla suvarṣiṇaḥ ca taravaḥ gucchaiḥ prasūnaiḥ phalaiḥ rāḍhyāḥ bhūri rasa pradāḥ ca paśavaḥ santi atra janma utsave  /
translated: Sri Narayana of the three worlds, the dryer of the ocean of poverty, descended on this earth with his six anvayas (lineages).🔽At that time, there was abundance of crops like shali rice, barley, wheat, etc., and great wealth of lentils, beans, corn, mustard, sugarcane, etc.🔽The clouds rained at the right time, the trees were laden with bunches of flowers and fruits, and the earth was full of abundance and gave sweet juices, and the animals were present in this birth festival.

original: gobhūhāṭakaratnadhāturajata bhūyo'pi bhūyo'nvabhū cchrīmatsihapratāpasāhanṛpatau bhūmaṇḍala śāsati /
analyzed: go bhūhāṭaka ratna dhātu rajata bhūyas pi bhūyas nvabhū śrīmat siha pratāpa sāha nṛpatau bhū maṇḍala śāsati
translated: When the glorious king Sihaprasiddhisahana was ruling the earth, there was an abundance of cows, land, gold, jewels, minerals, and silver.

original: kārpāsairbahulībhavajjagadida maryādayā modate tadvacchrīyuvarājajanmasudina sarvarddhibhavyārthadam // //
analyzed: kārpāsaiḥ bahulībhavat jagat idam maryādayā modate tadvat śrī yuvarāja janma su dina sarva ṛddhi bhavya artha dam
translated: The world, filled with cotton, rejoices within bounds; likewise, the auspicious day of the birth of the illustrious prince, which grants prosperity and wealth to all,

original: yadā chaunī vṛttā kṛtaruciracitrā hariharai rnivāstavyā bhavyā prakṛtiparisevyā ca vibudhaiḥ /
analyzed: yadā śaunī vṛttā kṛta rucira citrā hari haraiḥ nivāstavyā bhavyā prakṛti parisevyā ca vibudhaiḥ
translated: When the ground is made beautiful and colorful by Hari and Hara, and is to be inhabited by the fortunate and attended to by the gods,

original: hayānā hreṣābhirvijitaghananirhrādapaṭubhi stadā kailāśādreḥ paribhavati tejāsi mahasā // //
analyzed: hayānāḥ hreṣābhiḥ vijita ghana nirhrāda paṭubhiḥ stadā kailāśa adreḥ paribhavati mahasā
translated: Then the splendor of Mount Kailash is surpassed by the neighing of horses, loud like the rumbling of clouds.

original: dhanādhīśo yakṣāpatirapi ca rājendranṛpate rviditvā sadbhāva mumuca iti māna svamahasām /
analyzed: dhanādhīśaḥ yakṣā patiḥ api ca rāja indra nṛpateḥ rviditvā sadbhāva mumuce iti sva mahasām
translated: Even Kubera, the lord of wealth and Yakshas, knowing the true nature of the king, the lord of kings, let go of his pride and splendor.

original: jitaḥ kailāso me dhavalalayanairarddhaśaśibhiḥ sakhā me caitrādya vanamupavanaiścālakapurī // //🔽pumarthaiḥ prakhyātaiścaturupanataiḥ śrīraṇabahā duraḥ smābhūd gorṣāpatiṣu paripūrṇaḥ kṣitipatiḥ /
analyzed: jitaḥ kailāsaḥ me dhavala layanaiḥ arddhaśaśibhiḥ sakhā me caitra adya vanam upavanaiḥ ca alakapurī  / pumarthaiḥ prakhyātaiḥ catur upanataiḥ śrī raṇabahā duraḥ smā abhūt gorṣā patiṣu paripūrṇaḥ kṣitipatiḥ
translated: Kailash was conquered by me with my white palaces and the half-moon, and my friend Chaitra and the gardens of Alakapura.🔽King Ranabha, the lord of cows, became fully endowed with the four well-known human goals and the wealth brought by the kings.

original: tadanyūnāśena trijagati sa gīrvāṇanṛpati stadṛddhyā pūrṇaśrīriha jagati rājendranṛpatiḥ // //
analyzed: tad anyūna āśena trijagati sa gīrvāṇa nṛpatiḥ stad ṛddhyā pūrṇa śrīḥ iha jagati rāja indra nṛpatiḥ
translated: By the grace of that king, the lord of the three worlds, the king of the gods, is fully prosperous in heaven, and by his prosperity, the king, the lord of kings, is fully prosperous in this world.

original: sattvarddhyā bhrājamāno jayati narapatiḥ śrīmahārājarāje ndro'ya sapālyamāno lalitatripurasundaryadhiṣṭhātṛlakṣmyā /
analyzed: sattva ṛddhyā bhrājamānaḥ jayati narapatiḥ sa pālyamānaḥ lalita tripurasundarī adhiṣṭhātṛ lakṣmyā
translated: Shining with spiritual power, this king, the great king of kings, the glorious one, protected by the presiding goddess Lalitā Tripurasundarī, is victorious.

original: thāpāhīreṇa bhīmena sa jaṭharakulenātigopāyito'sau diṣṭyā jīvyānnarendraḥ śatamiha śaradā śrīsurendreṇa sākam // //
analyzed: bhīmena sa jaṭhara kulena atigopāyitā asau diṣṭyā jīvyān narendraḥ śatam iha śaradā śrī surendreṇa sākam
translated: Protected by the great and terrible Apa, Bhīma, and Jaṭhara, may this king live a hundred autumns here, by the grace of Śrī and Indra.

original: āpārāvāragotrāpatiṣu parivṛḍhaśrīmahārājasāha pṛthvīnārāyaṇānā jitasakalajaganmallabhūmīpatīnām /
analyzed: āpārāvāra gotrā patiṣu jita sakala jagat malla bhūmīpatīnām
translated: The great kings of the Pṛthvī-nārāyaṇa dynasty, the lords of the families without boundaries or limits, the kings of the world who have conquered all,

original: naptāraḥ pañcamāstepyaviratamavanīpālanāyāsakheda dvandvairnirmuktacitāḥ samasukhanicitāḥ śrīsamṛddhā jayantu // //
analyzed: naptāraḥ pañcamāḥ te api aviratam avanī pālana āyāsa kheda dvandvaiḥ nirmukta citāḥ sama sukha nicitāḥ śrī samṛddhāḥ jayantu  /
translated: Their fifth generation, free from the fatigue of constantly ruling the earth, their minds free from the pairs of opposites, full of the wealth of perfect bliss, may they be victorious.

original: saundarye madanaḥ prasannavadano nītyā prajārañjanaḥ śatrūṇā śamanaḥ khalaudhadamano gīrvāṇahṛnnandanaḥ /
analyzed: saundarye madanaḥ prasanna vadanaḥ nītyā prajā rañjanaḥ śatrūṇā śamanaḥ khala odha damanaḥ gīrvāṇa hṛt nandanaḥ
translated: In beauty, he is Madana with a cheerful face; in governance, he delights the people; in subduing enemies, he is the destroyer of the ocean of evil; in pleasing the gods, he is the delight of the heart.

original: śrīḍillīśvaravīrasenakalano dāridryavidhvasano thāpābhīmabahādurārpitadhanaḥ śrīrājarājārjunaḥ // //
translated: The art of the heroic king of Delhi, Vīrasena, the destroyer of poverty, the one to whom wealth is offered by the great and brave Bāhu, the glorious king of kings, Arjuna.

original: pratāpajitabhāskaro vadanacandraśobhākaro mahīpatiguṇākaraḥ svajanasaṅghadattādaraḥ /
translated: The sun that conquers the heat, the moon that delights the face, the ocean of virtues of the king, the one who is respected by his own people,

original: kavivyasanatāhara kṛtasapatnacittajvaraḥ aho raṇabahādurakṣitipatīndranapteśvaraḥ // //
analyzed: kavi vyasana tā hara kṛta sapatna citta jvaraḥ aho
translated: The one who removes the distress of poets, the one who causes fever in the minds of enemies, oh! The grandson of the great king Ranabahadur, the lord of kings.

original: pañcānā jagatībhṛtā puruṣaratnānā samuccāraṇā jjijñāsā bahuśo'nvakāri jinajenāryeṣu bhūbhṛtsu yā /
analyzed: pañcānā jagatībhṛtā puruṣa ratnānā samuccāraṇā jjijñāsā bahuśas nvakāri jinajena āryeṣu bhūbhṛtsu yā
translated: The desire to know the five jewels of men among the lords of the earth, born of the Jina, was repeatedly aroused among the noble kings.

original: taddāridryamahārṇavaprataraṇe naukeva me jāyatā svastiśrīyuvarāḍaya hi śatavarṣāyurvarīvartatām // //🔽thāpāvaśāliratnāvaliṣu surucira hīraka bhīmasena ya ca jyotsnottamāṅga tribhuvanavipaṇau sārthavāhairanardhya /
analyzed: tad dāridrya mahā arṇava prataraṇe naukā iva me jāyatā svasti śrī yuvarāḍaya hi śata varṣa āyuḥ varīvartatām    su rucira ca ca jyotsnā uttamāṅga tribhuvana vipaṇau sārthavāhaiḥ anardhya
translated: May it be for me like a boat in crossing the great ocean of poverty. May the auspicious and prosperous Yuvaraja live for a hundred years.🔽The beautiful diamond in the necklaces of the kings, Bhimasena, the crest-jewel of the moon, the caravan leader in the market of the three worlds, priceless,

original: uddāmasthānavāmakramaviṣamamilatkūṭamānairabhedya puṇyaślokāvatāra janaralasaciva pāntu matsyendrakeśāḥ //
analyzed: uddāma sthāna vāma krama viṣama milat kūṭa mānaiḥ abhedya puṇyaśloka avatāra jana rala saciva pāntu matsyendra keśāḥ
translated: Invincible by the cunning and deceitful enemies, may the hair of the king of Matsya, the abode of auspicious fame, the minister who delights the people, protect me.

original: kadācana purāpi no kṛtayugādijād bhūpateḥ svakīyapathamutsṛjannaṭati yātrayā'nyatra yaḥ /
analyzed: kadācana purā api no kṛta yuga ādi jāt bhūpateḥ svakīya patham utsṛjan aṭati yātrayā anyatra yaḥ
translated: In ancient times, the king, abandoning his own path, wandered elsewhere on a journey, never before or after the Kṛta age.

original: pracaṇḍaśivabhairavaḥ śikharisajñapūrakṣakaḥ sa kāntipuramabhyayājjanasahasravismāpakaḥ // //
analyzed: pracaṇḍa śiva bhairavaḥ sa kāntipuram abhyayāt jana sahasra vismāpakaḥ
translated: Prachandashivabhairava, the one with the name Shikharapura, the one who amazes thousands of people, he went to Kantipura.

original: yathāgatamajīgamaddhanumadādyaka dvāraka sa tatra pratihārakaiḥ sapadi kāñcu kīyādibhiḥ /🔽dharāpativacomṛtaiḥ kṛtavicitrapūjāvidhi rnabhasyasitadharmarāṭtithiśanau janairvāhitaḥ // //
analyzed: yathāgatam ajīgamat hanumat ādyaka dvāraka sa tatra pratihārakaiḥ sapadi  dharāpati vacaḥ mṛtaiḥ kṛta vicitra pūjā vidhiḥ rnabhasi asita dharma rāj tithi śanau janaiḥ vāhitaḥ  /
translated: He went as he had come, with Hanumana and others at the door. There he was immediately brought by the doorkeepers, the chamberlain and others.🔽With the nectar-like words of the lord of the earth, he performed various worship rituals. He was carried by the people on the dark fortnight of Bhadrapada, the king of the month.

original: dvitīyayuvarājaka pratilabhasva rājanniti pracaṇḍaśivabhairavo nivavṛte khagendro yathā /
analyzed: dvitīya yuvarājaka pratilabhasva rājan iti pracaṇḍa śiva bhairavaḥ nivavṛte khaga indraḥ yathā
translated: The king of birds, Prachandashivabhairava, said, O prince, receive the kingdom, O king, and turned back.

original: sarākakujapauṣamāsyaditime ca śuddhakṣaṇe dvitīyayuvarājako hyavatatāra sallakṣaṇaḥ // //
analyzed: sarāka kuja pauṣa māsi aditime ca śuddha kṣaṇe dvitīya yuvarājakaḥ hi avatatāra sat lakṣaṇaḥ
translated: In the pure moment of the month of Pushya, with Rahu and Mars, the one with auspicious marks, the second prince descended.

original: svāmiśrīraṇabāhadūravacasā rājyāṅgadhūrdhāraṇād gīrvāṇāgrimayuddhavikramavibhorlabdhaprasādodayaḥ /
analyzed: rājya aṅga dhūḥ dhāraṇāt gīrvāṇa agrima yuddha vikrama vibhoḥ labdha prasāda udayaḥ
translated: By the words of his master, Shri Ranabahadur, by bearing the burden of the kingdom, by the lord of the valor in the foremost battle of the gods, he obtained the rising grace.

original: yatrāste diśi rājarājasacivaḥ śrībhīmasenābhidho rājanvatyābhidhā'bhavaddigadhunā bokoṭaśailasthalī // //
analyzed: yatra āste diśi rājarāja sacivaḥ śrī bhīmasena abhidhaḥ rājanvatyā abhidhā bhavat diś adhunā bokoṭa śaila sthalī  /
translated: Where the minister of the king of kings, known as Shri Bhimasena, resides. O king, the region named Rajanvati became the Bhoktaksha mountain peak in that direction.

original: śivā rutamamūmucastriṣu pureṣu śṛṅgāṭake pradīptadiśi samukhāḥ sukaruṇāyamānā niśi /
analyzed: śivāḥ rutam amūmucaḥ triṣu pureṣu śṛṅgāṭake pradīpta diśi samukhāḥ su karuṇāyamānāḥ niśi
translated: In the three cities, the owls emitted a cry, facing the burning direction, out of great compassion, at night.

original: vasantasitapañcamībudhadine tvahirbudhnabhe tridhāṣṭavidhuje'bdake'niśamariṣṭasasūcakam // //
analyzed: vasanta sita pañcamī budha dine tu ahirbudhnya bhe tridhā aṣṭa vidhu ja ibda keniśam ariṣṭa sa sūcakam
translated: On the fifth day of the bright fortnight of Vasanta, on a Wednesday, in the asterism Ashlesha, in the year ending with the eighth lunar mansion, it indicated constant misfortune.

original: mṛṣaughamiha nālikha hyananubhūtapūrva tathā bhaviṣyamapi yatkalau vividhapratyavāyaśruteḥ /
analyzed: mṛṣā ogham iha na ālikha hi ananubhūta pūrva tathā bhaviṣyam api yat kalau vividha pratyavāya śruteḥ
translated: I have not written about the flood of falsehoods that have never been experienced before, nor about what will happen in the future, because of the various obstacles heard in the Kali Yuga.

original: tadeva hi kula kula nṛpatipṛthvinārāyaṇa kṣamājalanidhau pluta śuci sadā'talasparśi yat // //
analyzed: tat eva hi kula kula nṛpati pṛthvi nārāyaṇa kṣamā jalanidhau pluta śuci sadā tala sparśi yat  /
translated: That alone is the Kula, O Kula, O king, O earth, O Narayana, always floating in the ocean of forgiveness, touching the nether regions.

original: tapovanamavīviśad raṇavahādurasvāminā maputraracitāvṛṣī tribhavaduḥkhasahāriṇī /
analyzed: tapovanam avīviśat raṇavaha ādura svāminā ma putra racitau ṛṣī tri bhava duḥkha sahāriṇī
translated: She entered the penance grove, the wife of the lord of the army, the two sages created by her sons, the remover of the suffering of the three worlds.

original: maghau śravaṇame'site'ntakatithau vidhorvāsare lalittripurasundarī vasuvasudvipaike'bdake // //
analyzed: maghau śravaṇa mesitentaka tithau vidhoḥ vāsare lalit tripurasundarī vasu vasu dvipa eka ibdake  /
translated: In Magha, in the dark fortnight, on the last day, on a Wednesday, in the year ending with the eighth lunar mansion, Lalitā Tripura Sundarī was worshipped with two and a half Vasus.

original: iti śrītriratnasaundaryagāthāyā prakṛtiratna samāptam /
analyzed: iti śrī triratnasaundaryagāthāyā prakṛti ratna samāptam
translated: Thus ends the Prakṛti Ratna of the Triratna Saundaryagāthā.
